div.p: KNAVE, OR NOT? A COMEDY: IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER ROW.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p:
THE unrelenting oppoſition which the productions of the author of the preſent comedy have experienced for ſeveral years is well known, to thoſe who pay attention to our public amuſements. It is not for him to pronounce how far this oppoſition has been merited by inability. Since the appearance of The Road to Ruin, his comedy of The Deſerted Daughter only has eſcaped; and that, as he imagines, becauſe it was not known on the night of its firſt performance by whom it was written. Love's Frailties, The Man of Ten Thouſand, and Knave or Not? have ſuſtained increaſing marks of hoſtility: ſo that the efforts made to afford rational amuſement to the public, emolument to the author, and improvement to morals, have been rendered feeble and almoſt ineffectual. In the laſt inſtance, one miſtake appears to have pervaded the majority of the ſpectators. It was imagined that the author himſelf was as unqualified a libeller of mankind as Monroſe: in which character the writer's individual ſentiments were ſuppoſed to have been incorporated. Thoſe who have read his other works ſurely cannot attribute to him any ſuch indiſcriminate miſanthropy. The accuſation that has moſt generally been made againſt him is that he thinks men capable of gradations of virtue, which others affirm they can never attain. Perſons, who have made the human mind their ſtudy, have diſcovered that guilty men exert the whole force of their faculties to juſtify their own courſe of action to themſelves. To this principle the writer was ſtrictly attentive, in pourtraying the character of Monroſe. His deſign was to draw a man of genius, miſled by his paſſions, reaſoning on his actions, ſyſtematizing them, condemning them in principle, but juſtifying them in practice, and heating his imagination by contemplating the crimes of others; that he might ſtill maintain that reſpect for himſelf of which the ſtrongeſt minds, even in the laſt ſtages of vice, are ſo tenacious. How far that ſpirit of faction, commotion, and anarchy, of which the author has long been and is ſtill ſo vehemently accuſed, is to be traced in the preſent comedy may now be ſeen. Sincerely deſirous of giving no offence, the paſſages which were moſt diſapproved, or to ſpeak more accurately reprobated, on the firſt night, have ſince been omitted in repreſentation: but they are printed between inverted
commas; that the cool judgment may decide whether the author could have been ſo inſane as actually to intend to enflame the ſpectators, and increaſe a ſpirit of enmity between men of different ſentiments: whom, could he reconcile, he would account it the moſt beneficial and heart conſoling action of his life. The ſeventh ſcene in the fourth act is likewiſe omitted, in the performance: becauſe, inſtead of giving pleaſure, it appeared tedious. It is inſerted here rather to preſerve a neceſſary connection between the ſcenes, than to appeal from the judgment and the feelings of a whole audience.

Before the comedy appeared, all parties were anxious that no ſentence or word ſhould be ſpoken, which could be liable to miſrepreſentation. Some few paſſages, therefore, are committed to the preſs, which never were ſpoken on the Stage: particularly the concluding part of the laſt ſpeech in the ſecond act, where Monroſe enquires into his qualifications for being a lord. A few years ago, this would have been common-place ſatire: and it is a ſubject of no little regret that, at preſent, local and temporary applications are ſo liable to be made where none are intended.

Truth requires it ſhould be mentioned that, in the original ſketch of this comedy, ſome hints were taken from IL RAGGIRATORE, LA SERVA AMOROSA, and IL PADRE DI FAMIGLIA, by GOLDONI: but of theſe, though he has not lately examined them, the author is perſuaded ſo few traces remain that they are ſcarcely diſcoverable. They are mentioned, becauſe he conſiders the leaſt concealment of ſuch a kind as derogatory to that veracity which it is the peculiar duty of moral writers to inculcate.

lg.l: AMONG the various ways by wit devis'd,
To paint our faults and follies, undiſguis'd,
Through every age is found of moſt avail
The well drawn character, and well told tale.
Hence has the Stage become the laſt reſort
Of injured Innocence: her proper court.
"The guilty wretch," whom power and gold can ſcreen,
"Struck to the ſoul," will ſicken at the ſcene.
Vice that, with front erect and brazen eye,
In broad day pomp will paſs unbluſhing by,
Should he be ſeen but "ſitting at a play,"
How will his ſecret ſins that conſcious eye betray!
Pert Folly too, caprice in every freak,
Diſplays her feather'd head, and painted cheek;
While, "louder far than Wiſdom in the ſtreet,"
She cries—"Lo! Here am I! Come, worſhip at my feet!"
The thoughtleſs crowd, thus ſummon'd to adore her,
Hear, ſtare, obey, and proſtrate fall before her.
Yet let her be in all her frippery caught,
Juſt as ſhe ſhews herſelf, and hither brought,
The moment here ſhe's ſeen the witleſs elves
Laugh at their goddeſs, and deſpiſe—themſelves.
Fantaſtic changeling! Catch her? Ay! But how?
Th' attempt is bending great Ulyſſes' bow!
And yet again we come, with random darts;
Now aiming at your heads, now at your hearts:
But all in mirth, and with no ill intent;
At Vice and Folly our few ſhafts are ſent:
We ſhoot but o'er the houſe, or in the dark;
Hoping that you'll be pleas'd, whene'er we hit the mark.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: BY M. G. LEWIS, ESQ. M. P. AUTHOR OF THE MONK, THE CASTLE SPECTRE, &C.

lg.l: I AM angry!—Quite angry!—The whole of this night
I've been ready to burſt with vexation and ſpite;
And now am come hither in haſte, to diſcloſe
Why grief ſwells my boſom, and reddens my noſe!
In hopes a new road to your favour to find,
The maſk of Thalia I lately reſigned;
And, undaunted by prejudice, faſhion, or ſcandal,
Melpomene's dagger I ventured to handle.
My heroic exertions, the truth to confeſs,
By the Public's indulgence were crowned with ſucceſs;
For, when with diſtraction my boſom was ſeized,
I'm ſure, you all ſeemed to be mightily pleaſed;
When my poniard I drew, you applauded the action;
And, whenever I murdered, ſhowed great ſatisfaction.
Then is it not hard, that our Author to-night
Should have dragged me at once from my tragical height▪
My Briſtol-ſtone dagger away has he ta'en;
He has cut off four yards of my white ſatin train,
And preſumptuouſly begs, for the reſt of the ſeaſon,
That I'd try to amuſe you with nature and reaſon!
This prayer, I proteſted, I never could grant;
I had ranted and raved, and would ſtill rave and rant;
And I told him, this part, which for me he had planned,
Was not half enough furious, terrific, or grand.
I ſee not one Ghoſt through the whole of the part;
Cannot once find a place for a Tragedy ſtart:
My boſom I beat not; my locks muſt not rend;
Nor murder one man from beginning to end!
My diſpleaſure and anger reſolved to diſplay,
I called at the door of our Author, one day;
Was admitted—ſat down—cleared my voice—furled my fan—
Put my critical face on, and gravely began.
Says I—"Mr. Thingummy, plainly to ſpeak,
"Your hold on the public opinion is weak;
"For your canvas preſents neither Daemons nor Witches▪
"And your Villains appear in coat, waiſtcoat, and breeches!
"Now let me adviſe you your ſubject to change,
"For ſomething that's ſhowy, terrific, and ſtrange.
"That his Play muſt ſucceed, may the Bard ſafely boaſt,
"Who opens the piece with a Song by a Ghoſt;
"But in popular plaudits unbounded he revels,
"If he follows the Song with a Dance by two Devils.
"Obſerve too, you'll greatly increaſe the effect,
"If your colours with caution and taſte you ſelect:
"Thus, to make on the feelings a ſerious attack,
"Let your Spectres be white, and your Servants be black;
"And, to finiſh the whole with a ſtriking new Scene,
"Let a Pompadour Prince wed a Coquelicot Queen.
"Give us Lightning and Thunder, Flames, Daggers and Rage;
"With events that ne'er happened, except on the Stage:
"When your Spectre departs, through a trap-door ingulph her,
"Burn under her noſe too ſome brimſtone and ſulphur;
"Let Magicians and Monſters be poured on our view;
"And ſtick on your Villains a beard of pale blue Alluding to the Romance of Blue-Beard.!"
My remonſtrance was vain—He aſſerts, you can be
Well-pleaſed, when good-ſenſe, mirth, and nature you ſee,
Though his Play ſhould not leave you half dead with affright:
And I heartily pray, that the man may be right.
As for me (though I'm ſorry, my part won't permit
Me to ſquall at a Spectre, and frighten the Pit),
I hope you'll allow this performance has merit,
And though without Ghoſt, think 'tis not without ſpirit;
Which Spirit on Monday, eſcaping from Styx,
Will appear in this place—at a quarter paſt ſix.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: THY argufying, Harry, is all nonſenſe. Don't I know that I am Suſan Monroſe, the poor curate of Finchcliffe's daughter; and that thee beeſt my brother?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pſhaw! You are a ſimpleton.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, ay: mayhap I may. But I won't be wicked: ſo don't tempt me to pertend that thee beeſt an outlandiſh lord, when I know thee to be nobody but Harry Monroſe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be quiet; and liſten to what I have to ſay. I have always loved you, Suſan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, Harry, thee canno' deny but there's no love loſt.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Though your education has been neglected, you are a charming girl. 'Twere a ſhame that ſo much beauty and intelligence ſhould be buried in obſcurity. I am determined to make your fortune, and my own.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Not by becoming a wicked cheat! No, Harry, that's not the way.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You miſtake: that is the only way. "'Tis the common calling! For gowns, gold chains, and white wands are its rewards." From high to low 'tis all bargain and ſale. And what is bargain and ſale? Why to diſplay the good ſide, and conceal the bad: that is, to cheat and lie!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh Harry, Harry! Is all the learning father beſtowed on thee come to this? He ſaid, when thee run away, how it would be.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I have travelled, know the world, and mean to profit by my knowledge. Fools and knaves are the two grand claſſes: for the honeſt men are too inſignificant, and too few, to form a claſs. Poverty and diſgrace are got by keeping them company; and he that would thrive muſt ſhun them, as he would the plague.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Surely, Harry, thee canno' be in downright earneſt?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Such is the world: and ſhall I, like a driveller, make myſelf its football? No; it ſhall be mine! And I will ſpurn▪ it before me with the contempt it deſerves! While I deſpiſe and laugh at its prejudices, I will profit by them.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Look thee, Harry, I canno' tell why thee beeſt ſo bitter angry wi' the world. I can truly vouch I have met wi' many good folk, and few bad. And as to go for to ſay that thee beeſt a lord, I'll do no ſuch thing!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) I muſt deceive the obſtinate fool, for her own advantage—You miſtake the matter. Once again, I tell you, I am a lord.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh for ſhame, Harry! Don't I know that to be an un poſſable thing?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why! As if they could make a lord out of thee! Whereof a lord is a great—unſpeakable—Grandee!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! But I am a foreign Count. Any man may be created a Count, abroad.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Created a Count? Oh, what blaſphemy! But what doſt tell me about Counts, and lords? Here beeſt thee a kind of a ſchool-maſter, to young Mr. Jonas: which be a deſſunt modeſt calling enough; but not fit for a lord! It be a deuced puzzleation thing to learn to read, and ſpell, and put together; and I be very ſure a downright lord would never take the trouble.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well but, anſwer me: would it not rejoice your heart to be a lady?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What ſort of a lady? There be your lady ſuch as I ſaw go on a viſitation to the King's birthday; and there be the Taylor's lady, that lives in the alley and ſells red herrings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How acute you are, huſſey! Follow my advice and you ſhall ſoon be a real lady.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What and ride in my coach?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, girl.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Keep two footmen, a parrot, a lap-dog, and a monkey?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh a whole menagerie of monkies.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Wear high feathers, long gowns, ſhort petticoats, red ſlippers, and clock ſtockings?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Have my bed warmed every night, lie as long as I like of a morning, eat buttered crumpets for breakfaſt, plumb dumplings for dinner, and oranges and ſweetmeats for luncheon and ſupper?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Served up with ſugar-candy ſauce. Ha, ha, ha! Should you like it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Like it? How am I to get it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By getting a rich huſband.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What one of your London Squire Jemmies; with his thing'embobs down to his ancles, his hands in his pockets, his ſwitch in his boot, his impudent ſtare, and his hop ſkip and ſwagger "How do you do, my dear?"

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! By my ſoul, Suſan, thou art a jewel of a girl. I am enraptured with thy ſpirit of obſervation.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why look thee, brother Harry, if it be thy meaning that I ſhould lend thee my little finger here toward the cheating of other people, thou'll be plaguily cheated thyſel': ſo take warning. No, Harry, I love thee too well to turn my hand to tricks that ſhall bring thee to ſhame.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) Infatuated little fool! But I have her ſafe.—I find, Suſan, I have been miſtaken. I thought you had a kind of a liking for my young pupil? Hay? Nay, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Who doſt mean?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, ſiſter, no hypocriſy!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: May hap, Harry, thee beeſt joking me on account of young Mr. Jonas?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Indeed I am very ſerious. What if he ſhould offer you marriage?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, brother Harry, an' if he ſhould make me ſuch an offer, where would be the harm? Mr. Jonas be well enough to ſee to: and, thof he be a bit oafiſh and ſkittiſh, yet, i'the main, a's good conditioned.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: That is, you like him?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, Harry, it is no' come to that yet: 'cauſe why a's of rich parentage, and I of poor; whereby thee mayſt take it for ſartin, Harry, that I know how to keep my thoughts to myſel'. So I think nought about him.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: For what reaſon?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Reaſon enough. 'Tis little likely 'at his kinsfolk ſhould gi' conſent.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fear nothing: they ſhall! I have the means.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, marry! What be they?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Their own miſdeeds. He that would make the rich his tool muſt worm out their ſecret vices: he then has them in his gripe, and the tyrant becomes the ſlave.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Harry, Harry, I do hugeouſly doubt thee beeſt becoming a reprobate!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do not miſtake me, girl. I love not miſchief for its own ſake: I act but on the defenſive, and turn the weapons of oppreſſion againſt itſelf. My whole plan is this: I ſent for you up to town purpoſely to marry this headlong youth; who, if he has not the good fortune to have you, will make ſome cookmaid or kept miſtreſs his wife. I have lodged you here a few weeks to teach you a little of the town manner; and have brought Jonas to ſee you, who is mad after every woman he meets. To day I will introduce you to his mother, Lady Ferment. Prepare yourſelf, and act and ſpeak according to my inſtructions.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Sulkily) It ſignifies nothing talking, Harry: I'll do nought but that which is upright, and downright.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Angrily) Zounds, girl, have done with this abſurd ſtuff. I know what is right, you do not. If fair and direct means cannot ſucceed, who is to blame? Neither you nor I. Once more, obey my directions. Great events are on the eve of diſcloſure. Should you traverſe and betray me, I will never own you for a ſiſter more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then I wunno' be conſarned i' wickedneſs, Harry, do what thee wo't! No! I wunno'! I wunno'! (Ready to cry.) I do love thee dearly: wi' aw my heart and ſoul: and I would no' ſee thee come to diſgrace no not to be the Queen of England! So dunno' thee expect it o' me—But then a ſays and declares there be no wickedneſs i' the caſe. May hap there be not. I hope there be not! I do hope there be not!—As to Mr. Jonas, a' be a likely lad to look to. That there be no denying: A be plaguy rumbuſtical to be ſure: but, an it ſhould be our good hap to wed, I gueſs a'd be cured o' that—I do find myſel' in a ſtrange quandary. I be as good fleſh and blood mayhap as he. I be a woman, and he be but a mon. Yea, belemmy, we be aw Adam's children: but ſilks and ſatins make the difference. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.— Changes to the Houſe of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Miſs Aurelia, it is true. I think I never ſaw a neater turned ancle! And for a white arm, and a fine fall of the neck, there is nobody like you!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I am ſurpriſed to hear all theſe gallant things from you, Mr. Jonas; when you yeſterday confeſſed you were in love with your tutor's ſiſter.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What, Miſs Suſan? So I was. But ſhe is like the reſt of you: if I offer to touch her, ſhe ſets up her back, and darts her ſharp little fangs, juſt like the cat at the maſtiff.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Is ſhe a prude?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I don't know what you call prude, but I know ſhe won't let me come at her.—You are my mother's companion.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay. Heigho! Happy girl!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But I have been thinking—

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You had better by half be mine.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What does my mother want with a dear delicious—now I do.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why you are abſolutely a rake, Mr. Jonas.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A rake? No. I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What would Lady Ferment ſay?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What care I what ſhe ſays?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Indeed you are a ſad rake! You are ſo fond of the ladies!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: How can I help it? I wiſh they were as fond of me! Ecod there would be rare work.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You make love to them all.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No: there's one exception.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: My mother. She makes love to me.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And you treat her as you ſay the cat does the maſtiff.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve her right. She ſhould not be ſo fond, and fooliſh.

sp.speaker: LADY FERMENT.
sp.p: (Without. Calis) Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Tch! Tch! Tch! Here ſhe comes. Will you conſent?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I can't.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I dare not venture on ſuch a ſeducer.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ah! You have an eye ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas, dear, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Not what I like.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Aurelia, child, take care of yourſelf! This pet boy is becoming a ſad tempter!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A very dangerous one indeed, my lady.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That's a fib, now.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are, child. I am ſure you are; and it becomes young women not to truſt themſelves alone with you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ecod, you need not teach them that: they won't.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have been telling him what a ſeducer he is.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nonſenſe. I am not.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are, Jonas, dear.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay, indeed are you! I muſt beware of you, Mr. Jonas.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nah! You are all alike; with your flings and fleers.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: 'Twas lucky that my lady came!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ya, ya, ya! Ecod I'll go and kill the parrot, ſet the cat at the lap-dog, and give both your muffs to the monkey! [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sweet boy!—I am glad, my dear, you ſee your danger. Your ſituation, child, is a perilous one.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my lady, I am fully aware of my ſituation.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Come with me: I want to conſult you on a new dreſs. You have a very tolerable taſte, in putting on your things; and that is a great requiſite, in a dependent young woman. That and prudence, with a cautious tongue! Hear, ſee, and ſay nothing, is the waiting-woman's duty.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Waiting-woman, my Lady!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I don't mean you, child. You are ſomething above that: you are my companion.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is a new calling: your Ladyſhip muſt be kind enough to inſtruct me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I will, I will. Come with me: I will.

div.head: SCENE VI. Enter MONROSE, and MRS. CLACK.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: So, as I tell you, Sir Count, I am no tattler. I don't go blabbing to this perſon, and chattering to that. I have no goſſiping acquaintance to babble all my ſecrets to. I have put a lock upon my lips. I don't know how I came to make ſo free with you! But you have ſuch a 'ſinuating way! However, you are as cloſe as myſelf. Beſide, though you are down in the world, you are a gentleman, Sir Count; and, if I tell you any thing, it is as ſafe as in my own boſom.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You need not doubt of that.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Oh, I know it! I know it!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, and ſo—?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: And ſo, if what I am going to tell you of Sir Job and Mr. Taunton ſhould ever be known, I believe in my conſcience it would bring them to—dear! dear!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: That's my notion of the matter. But there is no danger that you ſhould blab.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You know me too well.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I do! I do! And ſo, I will tell you. Miſs Aurelia is Mr. Taunton's diſtant relation. She was his firſt wife's ſiſter's child.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: To my certain knowledge! And, what is more, ſhe is, as I have heard a ſmall bird ſing, the rightful heireſs to a mortal deal of money.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Aha!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: And, though nobody dare for the ſoul of them ſay ſo much, it's a crying ſin ſhe ſhould be cheated, as ſhe is, and robbed of her due.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Is it then known?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Oh, no! except to—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why, that—that is another ſecret.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay but, my dear Mrs. Clack, you are very well convinced you may truſt me.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I have truſted you with my maſter's ſecret; but this is my own. It concerns my own character; and if, at my age, I ſhould loſe that—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Can you think I would take away the character of my friend; who has generouſly opened her whole heart to me?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: It would be a baſe action in you, if you did! What can be more wicked than to tell a circumſtance that ſhould ruin one's reputation; after one has eſcaped ſo many traps, and ſnares, with as fair an outſide as any woman in the pariſh?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: And could I, think you, be ſo wicked?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I have lived in this family many years: in which time, as you may ſuppoſe, a number of chance accidents have happened: and if Mr. Quake—that is—Bleſs me! what am I ſaying?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Nobody: nobody at all. I was raving, I believe!—Miſs Aurelia was charitably educated by an old lady, who—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You have told me that before. Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why the whole blame does not lie on Mr. Taunton: Sir Job was the other executor.

sp.speaker: MON▪
sp.p: Pſhaw! I know it. Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why Mr. Quake—Bleſs me! I am ſo flurried!—Huſh! Somebody is coming! It is my maſter! Don't notice me. Why, Betty! Why don't you come? [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A word, if you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, Sir, that I don't approve your proceedings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am ſorry for that, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A fig for ſorrow, Sir. I will be maſter of my own premiſes!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Who ſo proper?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What right had you to bring this Miſs Aurelia into my doors?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh ho!—Lady Ferment wanted a companion.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Don't companion me, Sir! You come here a ſtranger, you give yourſelf out for a foreign Count, you are received into my family as a tutor, and before you have been three months you cajole my Lady, controul me, and introduce your madams as my inmates.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Moderate your anger, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I will be as angry as I pleaſe. I am in my own houſe, Sir. A'n't I, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do you doubt it, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, I do doubt it, Sir. No, I don't doubt it, Sir. What do you mean by doubt it, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Was Aurelia Roland then a total ſtranger to you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir!—What—What do you mean by that queſtion?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did you never hear her name mentioned?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I, Sir!—When?—What?—Where muſt I hear?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Are you wholly unacquainted with her family?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why ſhould the queſtion alarm you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A—a—a—alarm!—What do you mean by alarm?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: The Rolands, I am told, were formerly wealthy?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What—What is that to me?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: It is poſſible you might have heard of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I am—I do—I don't underſtand.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) The old ſhark! But I'll give him line for the preſent.—She is a charming handſome girl.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What of that, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I know you love my Lady: Yet the moſt loving huſbands are ſometimes caught tripping.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hay? What?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A city knight and alderman might have a partiality for ſo fine a young creature.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p:
Oh! Is that it? Ha, ha, ha! What,
you ſuſpected—hay?—Ha, ha, ha! That is very good! I perceive, Count, you are a wag. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! Heigho!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well, if any ſecrets ſhould have paſſed between you, and I can be of ſervice—You comprehend me?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hay? What ſecrets? How?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Any amorous follies.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh!—No. Ha, ha, ha! By my knighthood, never.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then you don't know Aurelia?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Know? I—How—Where ſhould I—Hay?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If ſo, I have been miſinformed.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How! Informed? Bleſs me! I—Who?—Informed?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, don't deny it, Sir Job. You know more than you like to confeſs.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No—no—n n no, I don't.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, you do.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, indeed; upon my veracity!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well, Sir Job, you have lived long enough in the world to know its maxims. If you ſtand in need of any man, you are wiſe and will make it that man's intereſt to be your friend. "You are an alderman, and a magiſtrate, and ſet a proper value on a ſmug wig, a ſmooth chin, and a ſhining pair of ſhoes. You have learnt the trick on't; and know that juſtice conſiſts in keeping gravity on the countenance, and money in the pocket. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!" [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Mercy on me! What a tremble I am in! What does he mean? He half talks as if he knew Aurelia Ro—

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What's the matter with you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nothing! Nothing, Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds! You are in an ague! How pale you are!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A little qualm. It will go off.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Where's your ſon?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What Jonas?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, your other ſon; the neglected Oliver.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I don't know. There's no peace in the houſe for him. Pays my Lady no reſpect.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Much more than ſhe deſerves.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Plays the very devil!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You miſtake: that is her part.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: She? Oh no! Good creature! She's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Then God help you.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: So tender! So loving!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: That her firſt huſband hanged himſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! He was a fooliſh man. I know how to manage her.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And ſhe knows how to manage you.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, we are well paired! I wiſh you had ſuch a wife!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The devil you do!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Such cordiality between us! Not but, if my Lady's nerves were not ſo weak, I ſhould often fall in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You ſhould?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh! I am plaguy hot, at times! Do you know, I am choſen Colonel of the What do you call it Aſſociates?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p:
Ay, am I! Why I am a man of war by
birth-right. My father was army hatter, and famous for inventing the Cumberland cock!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And I myſelf was once a contractor for accoutrements, grenadiers' caps, cartouch boxes, bullets, and buff belts. Nay, I have ſince dealt in gunpowder.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is that you talk about gunpowder▪ Sir Job? 'Tis unmannerly to mention ſuch things before ladies.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, he never does when your Ladyſhip is preſent.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh no! Never!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My deary is always kind. (To a Servant) Go, man, and prepare your maſter's chocolate. [Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! My lovy is ever thinking of me! Sir Guy called, chucky, to enquire after your health. He heard you had got a cold at the maſquerade, and was ſo ſorry! Was not you? Has been ſaying the civileſt things of you! Have not you?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Infinitely obliged to Sir Guy. Will you take a cup of chocolate, Sir, with my deary?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh no. I have juſt had a glaſs of bitters.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: They are very good for the ſtomach.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And Sir Job knows your Ladyſhip is excellent at preparing them.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I'll match her for that with any wife in ten pariſhes.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Deary always thinks too well of me. Did you take your new-laid egg, ſweet, this morning?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Surely I did! Lovy gave it me herſelf, with her own fair hand.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I have ordered your jelly at two.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah, precious!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your glaſs of Cyprus wine and a biſcuit at four.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Kind lambkin!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And ſome turtle ſoup before dinner.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Sir Guy) Do you hear?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are become a military man, Sir Job, and require a ſtrengthening diet.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very true. Ods thunder! Sweety will make a Sampſon of me!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A Sampſon!—Well, and how does your ſon Oliver, my Lady?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My ſon, indeed! He is no ſon of mine.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He is the ſon of your huſband; therefore yours.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ay, indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Unqueſtionably: if you have any regard to your character.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Who would dare to impeach my character?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I ſhould. Every body would.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For a baronet and a man of breeding, Sir, you have a very ſtrange way with you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I know it. 'Tis ſome people's failing to tell lies: 'tis mine to tell truth. But pray what are Oliver's faults?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A thouſand, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Name one.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I name?—Aſk his own father.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, let us hear. Come, begin▪

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Terrified) My dear!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have no pity on my poor nerves▪

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, I have, lovy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Count over your graceleſs ſon's pranks. Have you loſt your tongue, man?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no, deary: but you know my memory begins to fail.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My poor tender frame! Proceed, Sir Job, and don't ſhew yourſelf a ſavage! Paint your ſon in his true colours.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I will, I will! Firſt he is a tall, wellmade, handſome—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Handſome?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no! Ugly: a ſort of ugly fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well ſaid, knight!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has a bold, open, manly—Hem!—Inſolent air. Feeds like a hungry German at a table d'hôte, and refuſes to dine with the ſervants.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh the proud villain!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Aſpires to keep the beſt company.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: The worſt company: and, to maintain his extravagance, has audaciouſly petitioned for a hundred a year pocket money.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of a father who has only a rent roll of three thouſand per annum, and a plumb and a half in the funds.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very little more!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oliver is acquainted with your affairs▪ and methinks he might be very uſeful.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What's true, Sir Job? Have not you renounced trade?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: But not cloſed his accounts.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, my Lady: you know, I have not cloſed my accounts.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why will you dare, Sir Job, to talk in this ſtyle, and look me in the face?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no, my Lady! Not and look you in the face.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, knight, I think it is my Lady that deals in gun powder?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I ſee how it is! My nervous frame is not to be ſpared! I am to be thrown into a fit!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, my Lady!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why Sampſon!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Her ſit is coming!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Let it. I'll burn the feathers, and ſprinkle the water.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am ſurpriſed, Sir Guy, at your behaviour.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Likely enough: for I am ſurpriſed at yours.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are a ſtrange perſon.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay▪ many people tell me ſo. But I hear you have a young lady come to be your companion, of whom Oliver relates wonders.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oliver is a forward blockhead. Deary, I am ſure, won't like her long.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am ſure to the contrary, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, truly! I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: She is a taſty perſon; juſt what I wanted. I have ſent her to my milliner's; and on a few errands.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: On errands?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: One muſt treat theſe kind of people properly at firſt, or they grow familiar.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: If ſhe poſſeſs the rare qualities Oliver deſcribes, your Ladyſhip I gueſs will ſoon have her at a very proper diſtance.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: The greater the better.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: She came recommended by your Engliſh foreign tutor?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: By Count Monroſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! ay: Count. I beg 〈◊〉 Countſhip's pardon.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: He is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So is every ſharper about town.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A man who returned to England loaded with honors.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It was all the baggage he had.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have a licentious tongue, Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I know it. It is my plague; and it is a worſe plague to others than it is to myſelf. I warn your Ladyſhip to beware of it, and treat Oliver like your ſon; or I foreſee it will be buſy. It is the more dangerous too becauſe it deals in mere matter of fact. What it relates is credited; for I am notoriouſly a ſtupid fellow, without a grain of invention. I came purpoſely to tell you this, in a friendly way. Sir Job, remember your new occupation. Think how you once dealt in grenadier's caps, cartouch boxes, bullets, and buff belts. Be a man of war: my Lady will love you the better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Half aſide) Impertinent perſon.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay, lovy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Begone, iron-hearted wretch!

div.head: SCENE I. The Terrace of the Houſe of SIR GUY, at a Village near London.
div.stage: SIR GUY and MR. TAUNTON coming from the Shrubbery.

sp.speaker: MR. TAUNTON.
sp.p: NAY but why are you ſo pettiſh?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Becauſe I like it.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: An angry man, brother, rides a runaway horſe. Here have you every thing that heart could wiſh.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I have not.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To be rid of you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't be ſo waſpiſh, brother.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I will, drone.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Pray let me adviſe you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do, that I may laugh at you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Be conſiderate, be ſmooth. You are all fire and flaſh.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) And you are all froſt and fool.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: From the wiſe meek replies.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: From jackdaws fooliſh ſaws.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Nay but give me a reaſon?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Give you brains, you mean.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Why are you ſo ſnappiſh?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: For the good of my health.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Who ſaid you did?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: How is your health concerned?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Would you have me, like yourſelf, a compoſition of cheeſe curd and cucumber, tie myſelf up in a money-bag, impriſon my ſoul in the
circumference of a guinea, ſink to inanity with hearing it chink, and crawl to my grave like a pullet dying of the pip?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Neglect a penny, and ſquander a pound.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Pſhaw! An aſs is a dull animal. "Put nutmeg in your drink, eat muſtard, and mend."

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Patience is a good pilot.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You have leſs brains, leſs life, leſs propagation in you, than a Cheſhire cheeſe: for that will at leaſt breed maggots: but a miſer begins and ends with himſelf. I wonder who the devil made you my brother! Give me a fellow that has miſchief in his marrow.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Well but about this young woman, that you were talking of: you ſurely muſt be miſtaken!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You ſurely muſt be a mule.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her name cannot be Roland?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What impoſſibility has your wiſdom diſcovered?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Sir Job would not take Aurelia Roland as a companion to his lady!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Becauſe—Hem!—I don't know why.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No? You look as if you did.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Sir Job has ſons.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What then? Why is Aurelia Roland more dangerous to his ſons than any other woman?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: You juſt told me how Oliver praiſed her. But I am ſure it cannot be Aurelia Roland.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And how the devil came you ſo ſure?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Have you ſeen her?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aſide) Aurelia Roland? Impoſſible! And yet—Well, brother, I muſt bid you good day.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It will be the better when you are gone.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Patience is a jewel for a prince▪

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Patience is a preaching puppy.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't go to market to buy vexation.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I need not go to market, I can have it brought home to me.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't burn your houſe to frighten away the rats. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds and fire! This fellow would proverb a man to death in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Stay where you are, good woman.—Where is Sir Guy? As croſs but as kind hearted an old gentleman as ever breathed! He threatens the poor, as if he were their ſcourge: but he always relieves and feels for them, like the tendereſt of fathers.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what do you want?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Here's another pauper brought before your worſhip.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And how comes that? Did not I appoint you my clerk purpoſely to terrify the neighbourhood and drive away beggars?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: And ordered me never to paſs paupers from the pariſh without acquainting you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why what the devil, ſellow, would you have me ſend them away by cartloads, ſick or well, and ſuffer them to die on the road; as is the practice in other ſcoundrel pariſhes? Who is it?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: A poor woman with five ſmall children.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Thus it is when beggarly boys and girls couple and propagate ploughmen, and weavers, and the riff-raff of the land; who all conſpire together to maintain ſuch clever fellows as myſelf in ſtate!—Send her here!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: (At the door) Come this way, good woman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: How do you know ſhe is a good woman? Is not ſhe poor? I'll teach her better tricks, I warrant me!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now, miſtreſs! What buſineſs have you to be poor? Don't you know what a crime it is? Have you no huſband?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I had, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, he is run away, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (With her apron to her eyes) He is dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (During this ſcene, under the ſhew of anger, he repeatedly ſtifles his tears) Lord, Lord!—What buſineſs had he to die? And ſo you have five children?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Eight in all, Sir: five young ones at home.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Here's pretty doings! Here's impudence! Breeding of vermin at this rate, to people cabbins and commons, and multiply over moors and mountains! So that, if it were not for that politic purgative, gunpowder, by and by we ſhould not have an acre of waſte land left! Are you aware of your wickedneſs?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I hope in time, Sir, they will all learn to work.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, oh! What you mean to inſinuate that they will grow and come to be good for ſomething?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: If they don't firſt ſtarve, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
(Tears) Starve! To be ſure! What can they expect? Here's flying in the face of authority!
Where's the beadle? Pack her away!

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (Looking at Sir Guy) I don't think you mean it, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The devil you don't! Why this is worſe and worſe! (Examining her face) When had you a good meal?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (Energetically) Never, ſince my huſband's death.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Tears) Here's impertinence! (Again more ſtedfaſtly examining) When did you eat laſt?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Not theſe two days.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Tears: affecting great anger) Damn me but this is inſufferable!—I'll teach you! Take her away!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Where, your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To the pantry, you damned villain! To the pantry!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: (Drily) Muſt I paſs her to her pariſh?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do! Do! And I'll paſs you to the devil! Give her food; go home with her; examine, dive into wretchedneſs, and harden your heart, ſcoundrel; and then give me a full and true account, that I may learn to harden mine. And do you hear, you vile huſſey! Let me catch you faſting two days again, if you dare! Let me! That's all! In the mean time take this. (Gives money)

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: The prayers and bleſſings of the poor be your reward, Sir. [Exeunt Scribe and Woman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Damn me but it is very unaccountable! This woman I ſuſpect has feelings! And ſenſations! And thoughts! Nay I doubt whether ſhe have not
a heart, and a ſort of a ſoul; and yet ſhe is a pauper!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Here is a perſon in the parlour who deſires to know if he may be permitted to ſpeak a word with you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A perſon? A prig you mean.

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: By the impertinence and abſurdity of his meſſage. What mighty maggot am I, that a man is to aſk permiſſion to ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: You are ſo croſs and ſo kind, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir, how can I help it, if my heart be made of ſuch vile pitiful melting materials, that it is overflowing at every inſtant; and I have no way of ſhutting and ſtopping up the flood gates of paſſion, but by being a crabbed, cankered, damned choleric ſcoundrel? [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VI. The Houſe of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You are a witneſs of the humble demeanor I am obliged to wear in my father's houſe. I am the ſon of Sir Job by a firſt wife. He was then poor, and I am told I have no claim upon his preſent wealth; but that gratitude and crouching are due for the favour of not turning me out of doors.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It appears you feel your wrongs, but that you ſubmit to them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My father aids to inflict them unwillingly, and promiſes ultimate juſtice.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is for your brother Jonas' ſake that you are thus treated.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Not with his intention. He has the caprice and obſtinacy of a pampered ſon, but his heart is open and kind.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: This impartiality is to your honor.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Our parents and ſeniors are in poſſeſſion of their property, and the law tells them they have a right to diſpoſe of that as they pleaſe; but the hearts and affections of the young are not in their keeping.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but every day's experience proves the contrary.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Can the cold and palſied hand of age tie the delicate knot of love?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No: but, cold and palſied as it is, it can weave the inevitable web of miſery.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Ardently) Be it ſo! Let me periſh, ſo that I expire on the boſom of the woman I adore!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And is there ſuch a woman?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Will you not tell her name?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Yes, when I can perſuade myſelf ſhe can ſympathiſe with the ſtrong and throbbing emotions of my heart.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Heigho! Let us talk of the weather.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What are your thoughts on marriage?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Thoughts! It is a ſubject on which a pennyleſs damſel muſt not caſt a thought.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: But if thoughts will intrude?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why then thoughts are very impertinent things.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Viſitors which cannot be got rid of. Therefore what do you think of matrimony?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p:
That it is the paradiſe of pleaſure for a
few months, and the cave of deſpair for the remainder of life.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: It is the cradle of love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Say the tomb: and, love being dead, jealouſy, anger, ambition and avarice, all have full play.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What if love were vigorous enough to repel theſe ravagers?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: He then falls a victim to the petty warfare of caprice, dullneſs, and the deſire of novelty.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What if beauty and wit be his guards?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Alackaday! They are guards that always deſert their poſt; and when on it are ſo intoxicated with ſelf-admiration that they never do their duty.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: It ſeems, they are dangerous companions.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let you and I beware of them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I hope you do not follow the advice you give?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: If I do not follow, it will drive me.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To—Pſhaw! From this houſe. No, no; I don't know what I ſay! I ſhall be driven away by the arrogance of Lady Ferment, which my education does not fit me to endure.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Taking her hand) Then you are a ſtranger to love?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Fie! Have done! We are two outcaſts; but not I preſume the outcaſts of virtue. Her commands we muſt obey; and thoſe irrevocable commands are to fly the danger we cannot face.

div.head: SCENE VII. Enter JONAS with a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So, ſo, brother Nol! Theſe are your tricks! It's my belief you are a ſad dog among the girls.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: And what are you, Jonas?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Me? Lord! I am nobody! They only laugh at me! But I'll begin a new courſe! I'll be a ſad dog myſelf ſoon! You muſt know, I am confoundedly in love.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Whom? Why with them all! And it's damned vexatious that I can't get one of them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Jonas, beware: there is danger in your eagerneſs. Take a brother's advice, and don't indulge your appetites at the expence of your happineſs. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, pupil, have you finiſhed your theme?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh yes, I have finiſhed my theme; and a rare theme it is! All of my own invention!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am glad of that; it is a mark of improvement.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh I ſhall improve apace, with your help.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, and what is the ſubject?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay you muſt ſhew it me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Muſt! When?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You ſhould write nothing without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am your governor.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, we will not contend for trifles. I am your friend, which is better. Let me ſee what you have written?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You'll ſhew it Sir Job?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I will not indeed.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Honor?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Depend upon me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nay I don't much care if you do. My mother rules the roaſt, and I rule my mother.—I told you I had an inkling to Miſs Suſan.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, but—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: None of your buts, or I'll play you a trick. I like her. She's no fool, and can't chuſe but like me. So I have been inditing.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A love-letter?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I did it off-hand, at a ſmack. You ſhall hear. (Reads)

body.p: I am tired of being ſnubbed and ſnapped and croſſed and contradicted by my father: for, though not ſo old, I am as tall as he. I don't like my mother a bit better; ſo I ſuppoſe you like your father and mother as little as I do mine: wherefore I have a propoſal to make. I hate ſlavery; ſo if you'll take heart we'll be married, that we may both be free. The thought came into my head laſt night when you and I and the Count were at tea; ſo I had a mind to have told you juſt when I gave your knee two or three nudges, which did but make me think of it ten times the more: which is all at preſent.

closer.signed: Your loving friend till death, JONAS FERMENT.

postscript.p: Nota bene. An anſwer by the bearer is expected.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! An original compoſition.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Will it do?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You come to the point.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why not? I want to be my own maſter: ſo I want a wife, that I may be maſter of ſomebody elſe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: But you have ſaid not a word of that.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, when once we are married, ſhe'll hear it ſoon enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear Jonas, have not you finiſhed your morning ſtudies yet?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes. I have juſt done.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I make it a particular requeſt, Count, that you will not indulge the poor boy in ſevere application.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh leave that to me, mother.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why do you always call me mother, dear?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why a'n't you my mother?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Yes, my ſweet boy! But mamma is more affectionate.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Very well, mamma. (Mocking)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Or, now and then, madam.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I'll take care, madam.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And ſometimes your ladyſhip, or my lady.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh to be ſure, your ladyſhip, my lady.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ah you are a ſaucy dear child.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Harkye, my lady your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What do you ſay, bold face?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: If I muſt not call you mother, don't call me child.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Hear him, Count! Dear impudent pet!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, I'm too baſhful by half; which makes the girls all giggle ſo at me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ah! Let me kiſs you, brazen face.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, you ſhan't: I am a man, and I'll kiſs ſomebody elſe.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why, ſaucebox!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So I'll—I'll have a wife.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A wife?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, I will; and ſince you won't look out for me, I have been looking out for myſelf.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Mercy! Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I tell you, I have.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A pretty girl.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why, child!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I tell you, I am no child: I am a man, and I'll have her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear Jonas, have pity on your poor mamma, and tell me who it is?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: The Count's ſiſter.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Miſs Monroſe?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Her neck is as white as the driven ſnow!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: When have you ſeen her, child?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, I have ſeen her often enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Count!—She is poor.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I like her the better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Had you paid your addreſſes to a city heireſs, indeed! Beſide, you forget, child, you are to go on your travels.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What of that? She may go on her travels too. We ſhall have a young Jonas, and it will be a fine opportunity for him to ſee the world, like other travellers, before his eyes are open.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh! you dear, witty, wicked darling.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have opened my mind to her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: The right ſtraight forward way, to be ſure; by letter.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed! Count? And what anſwer have you received?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What do you mean by an anſwer, you ſilly woman? I have not ſent it yet. What anſwer ſhould I receive? She wants a huſband, does not ſhe? Beſide, a'n't I as rich as—as—as a ſilverſmith's ſhop, or a banker's money-ſhovel? Which is juſt what I want firſt—ſo give me ſome.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Some what, child?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Caſh. The ready.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You emptied my purſe only yeſterday.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What of that? I'll empty it again today.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nay, my ſweet boy, you are too extravagant.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I want a wife and money. You muſt furniſh the laſt, that I may furniſh myſelf with the firſt.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Pray, dear Jonas, ſpare me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Come, come; give me the rhino, or, look you, I'll begin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Begin what?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: To ſwear.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Mercy, child!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will, like ten troopers!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, don't terrify me!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Give me the ſhiners then.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I muſt not.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Then I'll ſwear away.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I ſhall faint.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Curſe my boots and ſhoes, but I will.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will by—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Gives her purſe) Here, here! How can you, child, be guilty of ſuch immorality?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You ſhould bribe me to be better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Money, dear, ſhould never be got by immoral means.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Then it will never be got at all.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: It would ſend us to a bad place.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ah! There will be a deal of the beſt company in that bad place. He that has money in his pocket is welcome every where. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, Count, your behaviour aſtoniſhes me.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (With ſtudied humility) Extremely ſorry to have aſtoniſhed your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Permit my ſon to viſit your ſiſter!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's ſon did not aſk my leave.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A youth of his fortune and connections!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: True: they are ſo great that, by your Ladyſhip's own order, he is never to be contradicted.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How came he to know, Sir, you had a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Very naturally, my Lady. I told him.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh you did!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I humbly hope the liberty was not unpardonable.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your hopes, Sir, are inſolent!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I bow to the mildneſs of your Ladyſhip's reproof.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I ſuppoſed you a gentleman, or I ſhould not have appointed you my ſon's tutor.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I hope my gentility will not diſgrace that of your Ladyſhip's ſon.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p:
Your gentility, Sir! Your title of Count
might give an eclat as the tutor of my ſon: but of what real value is it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Of very little, indeed, my Lady: it will not ſell for a guinea.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And may be bought for a guinea where you procured it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "Happy country!"

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But I will inſtantly put an end to ſuch proceedings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Let me humbly entreat your Ladyſhip not to be raſh.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Raſh, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I may well have been to blame, ſince doubts are entertained whether even your Ladyſhip have eſcaped immaculate!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I bend before your virtue, dangerous as the aſſaults are which I know it has endured!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You know, Sir! What is it you would inſinuate?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pardon me for having eyes and ears! Pardon their indiſcretion when the gallant Highlander—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!—The Highlander!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: At the maſquerade, led the ſcarlet domino ſo tenderly to her chair, ordered it to Clargesſtreet, followed muffled up—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I ſhall ſink!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Shall I ſupport your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Upon my word, upon my honor, Count—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady! I will champion your honor.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You ſafely may, indeed, indeed!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
I will ſwear it! And who ſhall dare to
doubt? The only boon I aſk is that my ſiſter may be your gracious Ladyſhip's friend.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But ſurely, Count, not my daughter?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: The Highlander, my Lady, was a remarkably handſome man!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (A knocking at the ſtreet door) I ſuppoſe this is Sir Job: what will he ſay?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh▪ your Ladyſhip and I poſſeſs the ſecret of making Sir Job ſay whatever we pleaſe.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed! Was he too at the maſquerade?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: He has been in maſquerade a great part of his life.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are an incomprehenſible man, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I ſhall find a time, my Lady, to make myſelf underſtood.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Here is a dreſſed up kind of country lady, that aſks for her brother Harry.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: So not knowing her, I kept her back with my arm and—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do not be impertinent, Sir. Show her up.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: (Going) Impertinent! This foreign Count takes upon him finely! [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: 'Tis my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I will leave you alone.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Shall I not introduce her to your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Introduce?—Oh, certainly! Certainly. I'll return in a moment.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Bowing) I will remember your condeſcenſion.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But my honor, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am its guardian, and who ſhall dare impeach it? We are friends.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Moſt ſincerely—I wiſh he was at the divle with all my heart. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE XIII. Enter SERVANT and SUSAN.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: There is the Count, Madam.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee, oaf, it was brother Harry? Thou'll believe me another time, I hope.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I'll take good care, Madam.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Giving him money) Here.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Oh, oh! That alters the caſe. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What has been the matter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, I curchied, and axt for you civilly enough: ſo a pulled and hauled me and made a combuſtibus.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You ſhould behave like other ladies.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Harry, Harry, I have no right to any ſuch title.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why not? Where is the difference between Suſan Monroſe and a lady?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why that be what I canno' find out. But what mun I ſay now thee haſt brought me here? Mun I tell how I left father in dudgeon and runned away i' the broad wheeled waggon?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Not for your life.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p:
I ſhall never perſonate myſel': I ſhanno' know how to demander my carriage. I ſhall neither
know when to ſpeak nor when to hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fear nothing; make your remarks freely on all you have heard and ſeen ſince you came to London.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay then belemmy I ſhall have enough to talk on. But you have made me dreſs myſel' out in ſuch tawdry flippets and flappets, ſo that I amſuch a mawx I can't abide myſel'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: They will ſoon hang eaſy on you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: There han I ſitten a long long hour while that outlandiſh barber, wi' his burning irons, wur a frowzling and a frizzling my top. And then, laſt of aw, a blinded me wi' dinging o' flour i' my face! No chriſtian ſoul i' our town would know me! I do believe they'd ſhout and ſet the dogs at me!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Curſe our town! Lady Ferment is coming. Up with your head, down with your ſhoulders, keep your arms back, talk away, and don't ſeem abaſhed.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, well, dunno' be croſs, and I'll do my beſt.

div.head: SCENE XV. Re-enter LADY FERMENT: they ſalute.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I congratulate you, madam, on your ſafe arrival in London.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, we came ſafe and ſoftly enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How did you travel, madam?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, I came by the broad wheeled—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By the Budworth coach, my Lady. But as your Ladyſhip hears my ſiſter ſpeaks the Cheſhire dialect.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, I dunno' much underſtand the Lunnun tongue.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have been ſometime in town?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Five weeks and two days.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Have you ſeen much of it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, marry, I ha' ſeen more nur any modeſt body could for ſhame ſay.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Pray let me hear.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but an I dunno' take ſpecial care I know my tongue will ſoon get o' the wrong ſide o' my teeth.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip will allow for your country education, and I am ſure will take nothing amiſs.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh, by no means.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then, i' my mind, as for your dreſſed up Lunnun moppets here, wi' their bare necks and painted faces! Marcy on's! They look as if—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: As if what?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I ſay nought.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You judge ſeverely, Miſs.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Miſs! Every Molly now-a-days be a Miſs! There be Miſs Hop, and her papa the dancing-maſter: ſhe be one of your high-flying tip-top Miſſes. Wi' her noſe toſſed i' the air and her trail ſweeping the ſtreet. Then there be Miſs Midge: her papa keeps a milk-cellar, and ſhe be a more bedizened and a greater Miſs nur t'other.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But, you do not think them all alike?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, truly: there be three ſort o' folk i' Lunnun. There be they that ha' more money nur wit, they that ha' more wit nur money, and they that ha' noather t'on nor t'other.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And of which kind do you think me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, begging pardon for my audacity, I do ſuppoſe your Ladyſhip may ha' more money nur wit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) Well ſaid, Suſan!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Belike your Ladyſhip ha' been ſo buſied i' ſpending your money you hanno' had time to learn much wit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) A ſhrewd gipſy!—What do you mean by wit, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That be a wiſe queſtion! Your Lunnun fine Madams hanno' the wit to make a bed, duſt a table, or darn a ſtocking. They canno' ſo much as ready their own hair, or fettle a cap; poor creatures! But are obligated to hire ſome needy body to do every varſal kind o' thing.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Then you think the needy have more wit than money?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, by my troth; and not much of oather.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh, the malicious little huſſey!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, child, have you executed my commiſſions?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To the beſt of my ability, madam.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Haughtily) Madam?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I beg your Ladyſhip's pardon.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh! Remember to be more reſpectful.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Aurelia with great attention and kindneſs) Permit me to introduce my ſiſter. (Aurelia and Suſan ſalute and converſe.)

div.head: SCENE XVII. Enter OLIVER.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Now, Sir!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Bows. Then aſide) I hoped Aurelia had been alone.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: None: or any that your Ladyſhip ſhall pleaſe to give me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: If you have none, Sir, your intruſion is unmannerly.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I beg pardon. (Aſide to Aurelia) Will you walk in the Park preſently?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Let me intreat you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I have ſomething eſſential to ſay.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: We have ſaid too much already.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is all this whiſpering? Pleaſe, Sir, to go and ſee if Sir Job is come in.

div.stage: [Exit Oliver intreating Aurelia by geſture, and ſhe refuſing.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Aurelia) I hope you will be good friends.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: (Giving her hand to Suſan) With all my heart.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And wi' aw my heart and ſoul too. You are a farrantly body; and I like you: that I do. I like you.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: While you ſtay in town do me the favor, Miſs Monroſe, to accept apartments in my houſe. Aurelia, come with me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Are you going?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I muſt obey: but I will tell you a ſecret▪ My reſidence here will be ſhort.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Behind) Are you coming, child?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You hear! [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Is not ſhe a charming girl, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, ſhe's quite a farrantly body; and I like her.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I knew you would. I muſt now tell you a little more of my plan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Hold, Harry. If it be aught againſt conſcience dunno' tell it me! Dunno'!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Pſhaw! I muſt tell you, and you muſt act like a ſiſter. Your aid is indiſpenſible. Liſten and guard what I ſhall relate as you would life. Aurelia is a rich heireſs, cheated by two old harpies; who want her out of the way.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marcy! Be that poſſable?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Literally true.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And dunno' ſhe know it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No, nor ſuſpect it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marry but I'll run and tell her.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Holding her) Are you mad? 'Tis I muſt tell her.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but wo't thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Moſt certainly. But I muſt wait the proper moment. I love her, and am determined to ſecure her fortune and marry her.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, but what an ſhe wunno' ha' thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why ſhould ſhe refuſe?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: She may have other likings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I care not if ſhe have.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did no' thee mind how that young ſpark and ſhe juſt now gave one another ſuch looks?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I did. I read their meaning. They ſtruck to my heart! But no matter: let me once have her in my power, let me ſecure her mine, and I warrant I will reconcile her to the diſappointment.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But doſt thee truly and faithfully love her, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: From my ſoul.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And thee wo't uſe her like a mon?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To her heart's deſire.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then ſetting that to be the caſe, Harry, I'll do my beſt for thee.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Seek her company, work yourſelf into her affections, and inſinuate thoſe good qualities which you know I poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I wiſh thee wur not a Count, Harry. Howſomdever, as far as conſcience and honeſty will go, I'll do my beſt. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Why ay! Succeſs, fortune, and Aurelia ſhall be mine! As for fame, give me but wealth, and that will come unaſked. And yet my curſed querulous conſcience takes part with my ſiſter, and upbraids me for being an impoſtor. Abſurd! Who are not impoſtors? Is any man the thing he ſeems? And, if feign we muſt, is it not better to feign ſomething that the world reſpects, than ſomething that it deſpiſes? The ſon of a curate, I have daſhed into life, met variety of adventures, viſited the Continent, and aſſumed the airs of a foreign Count. I have certainly diſgraced myſelf; but the world does not think ſo. Who would ſhew his naked face when a maſk is ſo pleaſant, ſo profitable, and ſo eaſily put on? My father gave me education, Nature gave me deſires, and I have
given myſelf a title. Why not? "If I am not a lord, it ſeems I ought to have been. I find no difficulty in being as extravagant as a lord, as proud as a lord, as idle as a lord, and as impudent as a lord. I could game like a lord, be duped like a lord, run in debt like a lord, and never pay, as naturally as if I had been born a lord. Let lords look to it, then, and reform. Let them be as ſuperior to the poor in virtue as they are in power, and I will bluſh for being an impoſtor."

div.head: SCENE I. The Houſe of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: SIR JOB.
sp.p: MY Lady is gone out, and we are ſafe enough here.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Safe enough? In danger enough, you mean! Were you mad or drunk to admit Aurelia Roland into your houſe?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What could I do?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: The orphan whom as executor you had robbed of her whole fortune.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I? It was you! You propoſed the plan.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And you carried it into effect.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You had one half of her property.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: With good right! Fools catch the fiſh, wiſe men eat them. (Half-aſide)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: My wife brought her here in ſpite of my teeth.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Half-aſide) The wife will rule when the huſband's a fool. As for me, I have proved it to you again and again that I have been her beſt friend.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay, then, ſo have I.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Do you think, if ſhe had known herſelf to be the heireſs of a great fortune, that her behaviour would have been ſo modeſt?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her manners ſo winning?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her wit ſo keen? She may thank me, and me only, that ſhe is not a vain, capricious, pert, prating, ſprig of faſhion.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, her fortune has been no loſs to her.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And a great gain to us.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: We knew how to make a good uſe of the money.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And to make a good uſe of money is to be honeſt.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes: we convinced each other, at the time, that we acted like honeſt men.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And now, at preſent, what would ſhe do with her wealth, if ſhe had it?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay, and how could we do without it?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She would know nothing of the price of ſtocks.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: She would never buy in at a proper time.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Buy in? She would always be ſelling out!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Inſtead of a good mortgage, ſhe would be for the purchaſe of ſome rake helly huſband—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: That would call us to account.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Cut our throats.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Blow us upon 'Change.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: File bills in Chancery.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Deliver us over to the ſword.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And the law.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: "And the church."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And the devil.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She muſt be got rid of.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I have a thought.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You have ſeen my ſon's tutor.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Yes: a keen fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has great influence with my wife.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Surely!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A bold, daſhing, impudent—one of your ſwaggering genteels.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Certain then to be a favourite with the ladies.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Secure him and the buſineſs is done. But do you know, from ſomething he ſaid this morning— (A noiſe heard without) Bleſs me! what's that?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Without) What are you doing, Sir?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Without) What is that to you?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: This way.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Sir Job and Mr. Taunton to an inner chamber.

div.head: SCENE II. Enter JONAS and MONROSE.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why did you kick the ſervant's bruſhes and pail down ſtairs?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Becauſe I like it. It's my humour. What buſineſs had you to let me go to that curſed hazard table?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I let! Did not I ſtruggle, and hold you; and did not you drive a pin into my arm, and break from me?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve you right! Why did you tell me of ſuch a pick-pocket place?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: We were paſſing, you read the word "Billiards," and I merely remarked it was a gaming-houſe.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Well! It's genteel. I like to game.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then you muſt be content to loſe.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But I don't chuſe to loſe. I chuſe to win. You ſhould have taken care of that.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, you. (Sulkily) My watch and all gone.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I could not ſtop you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nya! Who ſays you could? Do you think I am to be ſtopped by you?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas, dear, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Continuing ſulky) Matter enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Bleſs me! Something has happened! What is it, Count?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am ſorry to tell your Ladyſhip; but the truth muſt be known.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am ready to ſink! What?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have loſt my money.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: All! Yes; and enough too.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What a tremble you have put me in!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You always grumble to give me more. I have no watch now.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Is that gone too? You will ruin your poor mother.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve her right, for having ruined her poor ſon. So give me twenty ſhiners.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear child, I have not them.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Get them, then.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I cannot! Indeed, Jonas, I cannot!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But you muſt.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Where? Which way?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You know the way faſt enough, without my telling.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I can prevail on Sir Job to do any thing, except part with his money.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What ſignifies your wrangling? You know very well I will have them.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear, you cannot.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Can't I? Then I'll go and throw myſelf into the Serpentine river.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Cruel boy!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: "As ſure as you are living, I will.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I'll go.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake ſtay!" You will be my death.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: It's a death of your own ſeeking.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aſide) The reproof is juſt.

div.head: SCENE IV. Re-enter through the ſame door SIR JOB and MR. TAUNTON: the latter bows and paſſes on.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What, Count, have you and your pupil been walking?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, we are juſt returned. (Going)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide to Monroſe) When my Lady is gone, I wiſh to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I will attend you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Aſide to Lady Ferment) I am going.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Terrified) Stay.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Will you teaſe the old one then for me?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You know, good for nothing, that I will.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Now, lapwing! Where's your brother Oliver?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Bowing) Can't tell, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has he learnt better manners?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Don't know, Sir Job. If he would but have come with me, I would have taught him, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You hear, deary, what an obedient ſon you have got.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! The dog can be ſaucy enough.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Bowing) So I can, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! You can?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: It is not good manners to contradict my papa, Sir Job.
