sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You don't know, ſweet, how Jonas loves you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, that you don't, Sir Job: nor you never ſhall know.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What a happy man my deareſt is in a ſon and a wife!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very true, lovy. (Aſide) I gueſs what ſhe wants.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And I indeed am the happieſt of women. Yet it is in my lambkin's power to make me happier ſtill.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay truly! (Aſide) It won't do.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Will you conſent?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Certainly I can refuſe my turtle nothing. (Aſide) I foreſee a ſtorm.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p:
And deary ſhall have his Cyprus wine,
his turtle ſoup, and any thing my hands can make him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Thank you, lovy! Hem!—So you know nothing about Oliver?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How ſhould he, biddy? He is likely enough at ſome gaming table.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh! Five pounds to a crown at a gaming table! They are ſad places—vile, damned, pickpocket places.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Zounds, you dog, how dare you ſwear?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And ſo, deary, now to make me completely happy.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, my lambkin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: If you could let me have juſt a little looſe caſh.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I have no looſe caſh, deary.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nah, my ſweet one, if it were only fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hem! No more, jewel?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I perceive, Sir Job, you are determined not to make me happy.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) It is coming—I thought, lovy, that you were happy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your evaſions are vain, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) I wiſh Oliver was here—I muſt be going, lambkin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your miſerly propenſities are contemptible. I'll be the ſlave of them no longer.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir? Why is her Ladyſhip ſo angry?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is that to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide to Oliver) That's right! Stand by your father, you dog, or I'll diſinherit you.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are in no need of ſupport.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) You lie, ſirrah, I am.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Lady Ferment is too loving, too tender a wife—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: To need your interference, inſolent Sir.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There, Sir, I told you ſo.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: This uſage ſhall not continue, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No ſurely, my Lady. (Aſide to Oliver) Don't mind what I ſay—Do you know, ſtripling, in whoſe preſence you are? (Aſide) Speak up.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Bowing) In the preſence of Lady Ferment, Sir.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, Nol, you are a ſly fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR. J.
sp.p: Do you forget that I have a right to knock you down when I pleaſe? Bombs and gunpowder, get out of my ſight. (Aſide) You may follow me—Begone, you vile—what ſhall I call you?—See to the ſettling of that account with Paywell and Co. Five hundred nineteen ſeven and ſix in our favour. Get about your buſineſs you, you, you Saracen Turk!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Following) Why, Sir Job, I ſay—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I muſt have ſome money. The Serpentine river! Remember! I want pleaſure, I want a wife, I want a thouſand things. I will have ſome money. (Follows.)

div.head: SCENE VII. (As they go off, MONROSE enters.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What, is he gone?

div.stage: (Enter SUSAN from the Door through which Sir Job and Mr. Taunton retired.)

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Greatly affected) Oh Harry! I am main glad I have found thee.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I have overheard ſuch baſe villainy!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How? Where?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why a bit a gone I was righting myſel' i' the little back room there; and ſo I had ſteckt the door o' th' inſide; and there I heard a voice come into the next chamber and talk to ſomebody, and ſomebody gave anſwer in a gruff ſound, and there, merciful goodneſs, forgive me! There did they argument over the making away with Miſs Aurelia!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Making away with her!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: As I am a chriſtian ſoul they did.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You mean getting her out of the way, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, but that wur not aw, Harry, for they preſently talked over thy name! They did, as I live and breathe! And mentioned of thee being conſarned i' the plot! They did!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: If thee beeſt, Harry, if thee beeſt, Lord ha' mercy on thee!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Don't be frightened, fool.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but art thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pſhaw! No.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but art thee? I charge thee tell me verily and truly! Art thee?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Once more, no, no.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I doubt thee, Harry, I do mortally doubt thee! Lord, lord, where is ſhe? What wull become of her?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be pacified.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thou art a good mon's ſon, Harry: think o' that. Dunno' diſgrace thy parentage.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
(Sternly) Once more, girl, have done. I am as eager as you can be in Aurelia's defence. I
only determine to ſhare the good I mean to confer. Hark! I hear Sir Job! Begone!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Going) Nay but bethink thee, Harry: ſay thy prayers and defy temptation. Do do, for the Lord Almighty's ſake do! For I do mainly doubt the wicked one is often at thy elbow. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What an impaſſioned little fool it is!

div.head: SCENE VIII. Enter SIR JOB and MR. TAUNTON.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Now we are alone, Count, I wiſh to ſay a word concerning this young woman: this Aurelia.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Alone, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Mr. Taunton is my friend.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, and confederate.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Confederate, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, confederate. (Aſide) I muſt rouſe their terrors—Are not you of opinion, gentlemen, that there is a deal of roguery in this world?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Why I—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Perhaps there may.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Groſs villany! Legal robbers!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Are are are there?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: That plunder the defenceleſs, ſtrip the widow, and defraud the orphan: "yet aſſume to themſelves the port of juſtice, and condemn wretches in rags by wholeſale, ay, to the gallows, for petty three farthing thefts; while their own enormities are dreſſed out in authority, and law is made the guardian of great crimes and the mercileſs puniſher of the unprotected."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Are—Do do do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Taunton) Have you never known an inſtance?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Why I—I—Go with the crowd, if you would be kept in countenance.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) Are you acquainted with no ſuch perſon?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I—Really you nonplus me. I don't know what to ſay.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Say? Why ſay the truth. Say that it is a depraved, oppreſſive, deſpicable world; and that he who would live in it, if he would not be trodden under foot, muſt be like it. Come, let us acknowledge ourſelves knaves.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Knaves?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, knaves; and glory in having the wit to be ſo. Then men will fear us, fawn on us, crouch to us, bear us on their ſhoulders while living, and raiſe altars to us when dead.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Hem!—Men muſt ſell as markets go.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Really, Count, you you are very free. I—I—I mean ſevere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You miſtake, Sir. So compaſſionate am I that the ſecret you wot of hitherto reſts with myſelf.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Does it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: It does.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And ſhall it reſt there?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Humph!—That—that is the point in debate. There are two old gentlemen of my acquaintance, and I, who reſemble each other exceedingly.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Ay! In what?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: They love money; ſo do I. They wiſh to get a deal of it in a ſhort way; ſo do I. They have relations whom they would be glad to provide for at other people's expence.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And ſo would you?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If they are prudent we may come to terms: if not—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir, I don't underſtand all this.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No? Then you are very dull of apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Miſchief hatch, miſchief catch.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Taunton) Are you mad?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Serpents breed in ſtill waters. Do evil and look for the like.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well. Yonder comes a Lady who may quicken your faculties.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but hark you, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Since the gentleman does not know her, I will introduce him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake! Make your own terms! This way! Aſk what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, provided Sir Gravity have recovered his underſtanding.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Hurrying Monroſe off) I will be anſwerable. This way! This way!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Monroſe and Sir Job: Taunton follows muttering.]

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Noiſy fowlers catch no birds. Fools fiſh in troubled waters. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter SUSAN at one Door, AURELIA at another.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (To herſelf) That be the ſame gruff voice! For ſure they have been plotting together. Oh, Harry, Harry!— (Enter Aurelia)—Dear Miſs, I be glad I ha' found you!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And ſo am I. I am ſorry to tell you, my ſweet girl, that in all probability our acquaintance muſt ſoon end.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but why? I like you dearly! In faith and troth I do!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I believe it. Sympathy tells me you are ſincere. But I muſt quit this houſe.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Mun you? I be glad o' that.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: True: You are a witneſs of my painful ſituation. What! Hire myſelf to be obliging? Take money to be a pretty behaved hypocrite? Bribed to be ſilent when I ought to ſpeak, and to ſpeak when I ought to be ſilent? Submit not only to inſult but to deceit? Oh no! The terrors of poverty ſhall not compel me to that.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Do you know, I have a ſecret to tell you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay! What is it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, firſt of aw, brother has a liking to you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's mortaciouſly in love!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Surely you miſtake.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No no, but I dunno'; a told me ſo himſel'.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but ſurely, ſurely, brother be a likely mon?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I don't deny it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A made a poſitive declaration that a likes you deſperately.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: He is to blame. Heigho!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Mayhap your liking looks another way?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: My dear girl, I read the honeſt ſincerity of your heart: I will therefore own there is but one man on earth—and for him I muſt never hope.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: So poor brother has no chance?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh no, my affections are unalterable.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's well ſpoken! Well ſhaped! A has a mort o' learning! There be few can fellow him.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I grant you all; but my heart is gone.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then, ſin' it be poſitively ſo, aw's ſaid and done. I know too ſure that where one likes one likes: ſo do you take care o' yourſel'.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why I munno' tell! There be miſchief hatching againſt you: but I munno' tell!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Againſt me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I abominate ſuch wickedneſs, but I ſhould break my heart if any harm were to behappen him.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why—No, I munno' tell!—But ſin' you be for going, go. Lunnun be a wicked place! You dunno' know belike that you are what they caw a rich heir.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I rich.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: As I am a living ſoul you be. But do you make haſte from this houſe; and be ſure you let me know all about you! Be ſure you do, for mayhap I may ſee you righted yet. So pray you now dunno' forget me. I ſhall never forget you: and ſo I may happen to ſee you righted. Good bye. Lord Almighty bleſs you! Good bye!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p:
What can this dear warm-hearted creature mean? She has raiſed a thouſand tumultuous hopes and fears!—Whither can I go? To whom can I fly? Rich? An heireſs? Plots againſt me? Is it my perſon or my life? I am ſtrangely agitated! To take leave may be dangerous; and to depart ſecretly has the air of guilt. Fearful of others, ſuſpecting myſelf, and abandoned to a world of which I am ignorant, my heart ſinks at the proſpect.
But, like a traveller in a deſert, I muſt proceed or periſh.

div.head: SCENE XI. Enter SIR GUY, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Hark ye, young man, I ordered my carriage to take me up here: pray tell me when it comes.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A deviliſh fine girl, upon my ſoul! Seems deſirous to ſpeak to me—Your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Sir Guy, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You are acquainted with me, I find: may I take the freedom to aſk who you are?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A helpleſs woman without a friend, and about to ſtray I know not whither.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? Are you acquainted here?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I came to be the companion of Lady Ferment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you are my young friend Oliver's angel?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No, no, Sir Guy, mere mortal.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And you find your ſituation irkſome?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Not to be endured.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No wonder. What is your plan?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have none. I am almoſt tempted to caſt myſelf on the mercy of the firſt human being that will protect me.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Will you go home with me?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: That might be raſh: yet from all I have heard you have the heart of a man.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would not inflict miſery for the pleaſure of ſeeing it.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't be too ſure.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would neither deſpiſe nor add to the wretchedneſs you could not relieve.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't preſume too far.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would not contemn the forlorn, inſult the feeble, nor trample on the diſtreſſed.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds, Madam, do you know that I am a Baronet of ſeven thouſand a year; and that I am but man? That I have raging deſires, irritating ſenſations, headlong paſſions, and the means of gratifying them? Do you know all that?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am glad that you do.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: That I cannot look on you, young beautiful and unprotected as you are, without feeling a mixture of emotions, ſome perhaps kind, ſome ridiculous, and ſome—Come, you ſhall go home with me.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Would you not deſpiſe me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, for truſting me: or believing me better than I am?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Indeed I have not an abject ſpirit.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What do you praiſe yourſelf for? Don't I tell you that your ſmiles have enchanted me? Come!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Well, I will accept your protection for a ſhort time, but not an hour longer than I can find the means without ſervility of ſupplying my own few wants.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Heyday! Few? The few wants of a fine lady!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have no pretenſions to the character.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Huſſey, huſſey! By my ſoul I ſhall grow fooliſh. Your air, your ſhape, your looks, your
ſentimental prattle are ſo many Syrens. Come, come along.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am told I have dangerous enemies. Perhaps I am ſilly, but my fears have been alarmed. Suffer me to walk alone and unnoticed to the Square.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, but why?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I will give you my reaſons in the carriage.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, well; any thing you wiſh. Should you aſk me to marry, you are ſuch a bewitching ſorcereſs, curſe me if I ſhould not inſtantly comply. I am ſure I ſhould, ſo don't tempt me. Nor don't let my title, nor my ſeven thouſand a year, tempt you. Sit at a proper diſtance, and turn your eyes t'other way, or, in ſpite of ſixty-five, I ſhall be faſcinated. [Exit.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am happy once more to find you alone. I have been watching for it with tormenting anxiety.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My heart is overcharged almoſt to burſting, and will have relief. Pardon the raſhneſs with which I utter thoughts that I can no longer reſtrain.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay, pray deſiſt.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I have not the power. The tide of paſſion hurries me headlong forward; and, were death to follow like a thunderbolt, I muſt fall lifeleſs at your feet with the words trembling on my lip—I love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I intreat you to forbear! Think how we are ſituated.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p:
Till now I knew not how heavy a curſe
poverty and dependence can inflict. But I aſk nothing, hope nothing, ſave the aſſurance that you do not love another—Is that denied me?—Your ſilence is diſtracting!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You miſtake. Be pacified. Pray leave me: we may be obſerved.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Oh, that I could communicate but a ſpark of the fire that devours me! Surely the ſtrong ſympathies I feel cannot all be falſe; and they tell me, rapturous deluſion! that our ſouls pair inſtinctively. The mind that animates your beauteous form, and plays in your features, ſo harmonizes with my own that I ſeem conſcious only of exiſtence in your ſight!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Once more forbear. Affected coyneſs I deſpiſe. If I appear to fly you, 'tis the ſeverity of my fate to force me on that which perhaps rends my heart with as keen a pang as yours can feel.—Farewel! [Exit.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Farewel! Why farewel? Aurelia! [Exit following.

div.head: SCENE I. The Houſe of Mr. QUAKE.
div.stage: Enter MONROSE and QUAKE, the latter alarmed.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: BF kind enough to ſtay there, Mr. Buffalo, with your aſſiſtants, and let nobody paſs.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: What is the reaſon of this, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be patient. You'll hear ſoon enough. I think, Mr. Quake, you have long been the attorney of Mr. Taunton?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Yes.—Yes, Sir—for thirty years.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Have tranſacted all his ſecret concerns?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I, Sir, I—I have done his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but his ſecret buſineſs?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON
sp.p: Can't you gueſs?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did you never hear of one Admiral Roland?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: (Aſide) Mercy!—No.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why do you tremble?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Me? I am a little nervous. I am very ill. I am taken I don't know how.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No; you are not taken yet: they are only waiting for you.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: For me, Sir? What have I done?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Aided and abetted in robbing an orphan.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy I never robbed any body in my life; out of the honeſt way of my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, but the honeſt way of your profeſſion won't ſave your neck, though you are a lawyer, unleſs Aurelia Roland and her fortune too be forthcoming.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I have not a farthing of her fortune, Sir.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Evaſion is only waſte of time. Aurelia Roland has been forced or lured away from the houſe of Sir Job.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: If ſhe has, I have had no concern in it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: But you know where ſhe is, Goodman Quibble.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Who could tell you that, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: An intimate friend of yours, Sir; to whom you tell all your ſecrets. Mrs. Clack.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: (Aſide) The devil take Mrs. Clack—I happened to be paſſing through the Square; and there, by accident—I ſaw Miſs Roland ſtep into the carriage with Sir Guy Taunton.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, oh! With Sir Guy! It ſeems then, by accident, you do know her; and, by accident, you muſt remain in the cuſtody of theſe gentlemen without: that I may be ſure of your teſtimony when it is wanted.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I in cuſtody, Sir? 'Tis a lawyer's buſineſs to put people in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Or that or immediately go with me before a magiſtrate. Your character will then be blown paſt all remedy. If you comply and behave prudently, you may ſtill perhaps be ſuffered to wear the maſk of honeſty.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you wrong me. I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: As honeſt as I could be, and do my duty.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Your duty!

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; my duty. I was Mr. Taunton's attorney. Had I betrayed my employer, nobody would ever have truſted me again. I was guilty of no more roguery than was neceſſary to keep a good character in the world.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, Old Logic! Thou ſay'ſt true. Thine is the current morality. That which is a man's intereſt is his duty. But come, decide: will you remain in cuſtody for a ſhort time or—?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: In cuſtody, Sir, ſince it muſt be ſo. Though indeed I have fingered no part of this lady's fortune.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No, Sir! Why then you have been both knave and fool.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I fear as much.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You an attorney? Baw! You have not yet learned your rudiments. "What is a blockhead? A blockhead is a poor devil. Who are men of underſtanding? Every one who has five thouſand a year. What is a knave? He that is hanged for cheating. And what an honeſt man? He that gets an eſtate by the ſame means. Who are moſt courted? Men of wit. And who are they? Thoſe that give good dinners, make their friends drunk with the beſt wines, and then pick their pockets at hazard and faro. Who are moſt imitated? Men of faſhion. And he is a man of the firſt faſhion who aſſociates with ſtable-boys in the morning, with opera-dancers and demireps after dinner, and with a Babel mixture of bullies, bubbles, and pickpockets from midnight to ſunriſe." [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. Changes to the houſe of SIR JOB, with a cloſet door.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p:
I can have no frolic till I get ſome money. Since we moved from the City, Sir Job keeps his looſe caſh, as he calls it, in that cloſet. If it were not for locks I could get at it; and then it would ſoon be looſe enough. If I had got poſſeſſion, I would make my mother give it me; and there is no harm in taking what is freely given. (Examines and finds
the door unlocked) Hay! Why the door is open! Who knows? Now for good luck! (Goes into the cloſet.)

div.head: SCENE III. Enter LADY FERMENT and OLIVER.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Are you ſure, Sir, you know nothing of her?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Only that ſhe is gone.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A very ſtrange proceeding indeed! Leave my houſe without ſaying a word?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I intreated her to tell where ſhe was going; but ſhe refuſed.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And how came you to know ſhe was going?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I—I queſtioned her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your oglings, Sir, have been remarked; and I ſuſpect you have been her eſcort.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Aſide) Would that I had!—I have been on my father's buſineſs to receive this money.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may leave the money with me.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam. I am accountable.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Impertinence! Have you ſeen the Count?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: No, my Lady.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Where can Jonas be gone? Wild thing! He is never a moment in a place. (Looks into an adjoining chamber).

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My father has got the key of the cloſet, and I muſt keep this heavy bag in poſſeſſion till he comes. (Looks round) The door is a-jar! Perhaps, knowing where I was gone, he left it open purpoſely. This is fortunate. (Goes into the cloſet.)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I can't ſee him. Where is this inſolent youth gone with the money?

div.stage: (Oliver returns, and ſhuts the door after him).

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There, there. This ſpring lock will keep it ſafe enough.—When Sir Job comes in, my Lady, be kind enough to tell him I am waiting to pay the balance for which he ſent me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: That is lucky, however. He cannot now pretend he has no caſh. I muſt get ſome for this dear tormenting boy. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Peeping out, having overheard) He has got ſome for himſelf. (Toſſing the guineas) Here's pleaſure! Here's frolic! Here's watches, and rings, and ribbands for Suſan! Oh lord! Oh lord! I was ſnug in the corner: Oliver could not ſee me. Ha, ha, ha! I have filled up the bag with counters. Hold! I muſt ſhut the door; and then this ſpring lock will make all ſafe. Your ſpring lock is a kind of politician's puzzle: he that is in can eaſily get out; but he that is out muſt procure a key. (Shaking the guineas) Here they are! Where ſhall I find Suſan? Here's muſic! Here they are! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE V. Enter SIR JOB, OLIVER, and LADY FERMENT.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: There is a bill below for five hundred pounds, waiting payment: have you been where I ordered you?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) It is lucky this bill is come for payment: elſe, knowing I had money in the houſe, I ſhould have had no peace with my Lady.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Preſenting bills) Here are four hundred and fifteen bank; and a hundred guineas in that cloſet.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Go and fetch them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You have the key, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Then how did you get in?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: The door was open.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, I remember. (Gives the key) I had no caſh, as I told you, deary; ſo, ha, ha, ha! I was not afraid of being robbed. (Oliver returns with the bag. Sir J. feeling) What is here, Sir? This neither weighs nor feels like guineas.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I counted and put them in myſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Indeed! Then my touch deceives me. (Takes out a handful) Heyday! Why, what the devil are theſe?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Is this witchcraft?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You counted them yourſelf!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am thunder-ſtruck!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Mercy! If this ſhould be a trick of Jonas'!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Sir Job, my Lady, if the tongue of man be capable of truth, I left this bag, or one like it, with a hundred guineas in that cloſet not twenty minutes ago. Your Ladyſhip ſaw me go in.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: (Without) Leave off!

sp.speaker: JONAS.
sp.p: (Without) I muſt kiſs you!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Entering) I wunno' be poo'd and hawd a this'n!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What uproar is this?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Aſide) The ſport is ſpoiled: I hoped there was nobody here.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Oliver) How dare you ſtay in this houſe, you vile—I have no name bad enough for you. Get out of my doors!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What is the matter, Nol?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am charged with fraud, with robbery, brother.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Whoo! (Lady Ferment reprimands Jonas by geſtures)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I juſt now left a bag with a hundred guineas in that cloſet, which has been ſtolen, and I am to be turned adrift like a felon.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Are you?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he is!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Curſe me if he ſhall. Nol is no thief.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How do you know, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nol is no thief, I ſay.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Then who ſtole my hundred guineas?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why, look you—If it was ſtealing, I ſtole them.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And where are they, dog?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Liſten! Hark!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Jonas jingles them in his pocket, and ſlips away when Sir Job endeavours to ſeize him) You impudent, confounded whelp!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nol! Will you have a few? I know you are at ſhort commons.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Jonas, though this is a bad trick, I am glad to find you have an honeſt and a generous heart. Yet conſider the conſequences of this thoughtleſs conduct. Think that a brother, whom you love, has been accuſed of theft; and in danger of ſuffering all the diſgrace which ſuch a vice well deſerves.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Oliver, Sir Job, and Lady Ferment: the two latter reprimanding Jonas by geſture.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I believe it was not quite right, but I have no time juſt now to be ſorrowful—Harkye, Suſan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What ſayn you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Look! What a ſweet pretty robin redbreaſt!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (After looking) Where?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Look! Look! Can't you ſee it? (Locks the door ſlily)

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Shewing the key) In its cage.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh the cunning ſly tooad!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have her now!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: How ſhall I get away? A's a deſperate wicked one!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Now we are fairly alone, I have a ſecret to tell you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay marry! What be that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why that I am confoundedly in love.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: In love be you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord! Yes.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, an you be got in, the beſt way will be to get out again.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That's juſt my intention, and you muſt help me.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aſide) What i'the name of goodneſs ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But firſt tell me, what is your opinion of me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Of you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ay; what do you think of me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: By the mackins, I think you bin a queeriſh kind of a youth!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, by the maſs do I!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why then there is a pair of us. But, queer as I am, could you like me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Like you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ay: love me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy. (Jonas approaches and ſhe puſhes him back) Beſt when furtheſt off.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nah now—I want a wife, and I like you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aſide) An I dunno' coax'n, I ſhall ne'er get away. I wiſh I had the key.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Am I to your taſte?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I canno' tell. In our town, it's taſte and try. We always bite afore we buy.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Going to kiſs her) Oh! with all my heart!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay: hold a blow! Pray now did you ever play at kiſſes and commands?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No: but I ſhould like to play at them exceedingly.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well then, I'll learn you how.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord, do! That is the very game I want to be at! I would fain both kiſs and command.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: It's a this'n. You be to kiſs when I command.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That I will with all my ſoul!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And I be to kiſs when you command.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord! Better and better! Come, let us begin.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but you be in too much a haſte. Firſt we are to pay our forfeits: ſo then the game begins.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Come then pay away! Oh, it will be rare ſport! Here; here. Take the guineas firſt.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No. I wunno' foul my fingers wi' they.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why I got them purpoſely for you!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I tell you, I wunno' come near them.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p:
Well, well, here's my handkerchief, and my pocket-book, and my pencil-caſe, and my
knife—No; I'll not give my knife: that cuts love.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Is that aw? Feel i'your coat pocket; for, you know, the more forfeits—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, ay! The more kiſſes! Here! Take my gloves: two, mind, two: and the key, and—ſtay, ſtay! I'll give you my knee-buckles, and my ſhoe-buckles, and—

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Hold a bit. I ha' enow now. So you be to hold your hat for mine.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Here it is. Make haſte!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Pretending to feel in her pockets) By the mackins, i'this dowdy dreſs, I ha' got welly nought about me—Hold—In our town, the laſſes ſometimes gi' the lads their mittens, and their neckkerchiefs, and— (Baſhfulneſs) And their garters.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Do they? Let me have them!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But then the lads awways turn about, you know, wi' their▪ faces t'other way.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Turning) What, ſo?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, a that'n: but go a bit a gait.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A gait! What's that?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: More further off.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Retreating to the door) Nigher to the wall—Nigher yet—Now don't you turn!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What, not one peep?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh, no! for an you do the game's over!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Well, make haſte.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Dunno' you look. Stand ſtock ſtill. I ha' welly done. (Having unlocked the door and gone out, ſhe peeps in) You may turn about, now.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Hay! What! Are theſe your tricks?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Look! Look! What a pretty robin redbreaſt there be! (Bangs-to the door.)

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh you confounded little jade, but I ſhall catch you! Well, it is plaguy tantalizing when one is in ſuch a hurry to be married, to be balked ſo often. Oh that I had a chaiſe and eight now at the door, and this dear little gipſy in my arms! She would ſtruggle: ſo ſhould I. "Pray, Mr. Jonas, let me go!" I can't, my love! "Conſider my bluſhes!" Conſider my impatience! "Nay but duty, decency!" Are both drabs; a queer pair of prudes; two frumpiſh freakiſh old-faſhioned tabbies; all polite people now are aſhamed of their company. So let us leave them to their favourite friends, old maids cabal and a brandy bottle, and hey for Scotland, you ſweet charming— (Going)

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter MONROSE, bringing in SUSAN by the wriſt.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Again.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Leave us, Sir.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Leave you, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes; I can't waſte time in trifling, and am in no humour for compliments. Leave us.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You might be in a humour for good manners, methinks. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: The beeſt woundy crabbed, Harry.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
What is the reaſon, madam, that you thus counteract me in my faireſt proſpects, and my deareſt hopes? How dare you traverſe me at the
very moment when miſery or happineſs ſupreme depends on the event? Why did you alarm Aurelia, and adviſe her to fly?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That my conſcience mought no' fly i' my face, Harry, as thine will do.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Your conſcience! Was it your conſcience that told you to betray your brother?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea belemmy wur it. But I would no' give ear to my conſcience, ſo I ſaid nought that could harm a hair o' thy head.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How! Did not you tell me yourſelf, juſt as we were interrupted, that you had betrayed me to her?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, by my troth did not I. I only towd thee how I towd ſhe how deſperately thee ſaid thee wur in love. So ſhe ſaid ſhe wur mortal ſorry for it: for why? She had fixed her liking elſewhere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, ay: on this Oliver. Damned fortune! I am her ſaviour. She is mine in equity, and mine ſhe ſhall be.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Then what does thee mean to do, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Secure her, win her, poſſeſs her. Obſerve what I ſay, and for your life dare not this time to ſwerve one tittle from what I preſcribe. Send for a coach, return to your lodging, and be ready to receive her. She will be there within an hour.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That canno' be, Harry. I be mortal ſure ſhe wunno' come of her own good will.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Good-will or ill-will, come ſhe ſhall; and there I tell you ſhe will be. Prepare, therefore, to aid me, as I order you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thee may'ſt order what the wo't, Harry; but I'll be conſarned i' no ſuch deformity.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Damnation! Am I to be eternally
thwarted thus by a mere puppet! Once more, girl, liſten and obey.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thee may'ſt fell me at thy feet, thee may'ſt kill me, an thee wo't, Harry; but I wunno'. I have ſaid it, and I wunno'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Hell and— (Snatches out his watch, ſees the hour, and haſtily croſſes) Hark you, I know not how far your infernal obſtinacy may lead you▪ You have already injured me deeply; but, ſhould you venture to whiſper one more treacherous word, tremble at my vengeance. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marcy keep me, what a wicked paſſion a be in! A'll come to no good; and my heart wull bruſt. What ſhall I do? I have no chriſtian ſoul to break my mind to. A ſaid a would bring poor Miſs Aurelia to my lodging. What if I do go and ſome how watch? Who knows but I mought ſave her from ruination, and betray him from a mort o' miſchief? I munno' tell ought, for then belike a wull be taken up; and what mought betide, oh Lord! Oh Lord! Suppoſing him before the juſtice!—I'll do't—I wull—I'll ſay my prayers and ventur, I'm detarmint. (Going)

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Stop! Stop a moment!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Angrily) Keep a gait, then! Do.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: My ſweet girl, there is ſomething the matter with you. I know there is, ſo don't deny it. Here I am, and if I can do you any ſervice, curſe me but I ſhall jump out of my ſkin for joy.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, no, I ha' no ſoul on earth to open my boſom to.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What then you dare not truſt me? Damn it, I did not think you had thought ſo ill of me as that!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: An any harm were to befaw him (Weeping bitterly) I ſhould never more be i' my right mind. I love him from my very heart's core. A's my only brother. A has tricks, but a's a fine mon. There be few like him; an if a ſhould no' die in his bed, Lord ha' marcy upon me! I ſhould go raving melancholy.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Dry your eyes. He ſhall not die at all. We'll ſave him. I'll manage the matter.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why wull you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I hate liſteners, and yet I liſtened and heard all.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did you, for ſure?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And will you be true and faithfoo'?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: If I am not hate me. You have not betrayed his ſecrets, mind: you have told nothing. I'll ſave him.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Wull you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: An you do, I ſhall love you to the longeſt breath I draw.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I hope ſo, for I ſhall love you longer▪ You are the ſweeteſt, bewitching—

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, but bethink you. Shall I go to the lodging houſe?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Do. It may prevent miſchief.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, and how then?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, I have it! Brother Nol and old gruff Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but that will betray Harry!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Not a bit. They are noble ſouls! Sound hearts! They would not hurt man, woman, or child. Do you make haſte. I muſt fly. I ſhall accompliſh it; and then, oh Lord, oh Lord! I ſhall be a happy dog! [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's a greadly lad! A's a farrantly lad! And I be welly overcome to think a has ſo kind a heart! An a make his words good, I do believe I ſhall love him ten thouſand times better nur I do brother Harry! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. The Lodgings of SUSAN. Loud knocking at the Street Door.
div.stage: Enter SUSAN haſtily and in much alarm.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: SO, ſo! A be come at long length. (Knocking again) A's in a wicked haſte—There—the door opens—Now for it! What wull be the upſhot on't?—Goodneſs, how dizzy I be!—Dear, dear, what be come to me!—I am taken all over as thof I had an ague fit—I mun bear up—I hear him—A be coming—Marcy deliver me! (Retires.)

div.head: SCENE II. (Enter MONROSE and AURELIA, preceded by a Female Servant with Candles, which ſhe places on the Table and departs.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Let me intreat you to quiet your alarms, you are ſafe.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Safe! Inſulting mockery! Why have I been forced here? What is your purpoſe?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Kind as your heart could wiſh.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Are falſehood, artifice, and outrage kind?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Blame the depravity which not merely juſtifies but renders them unavoidable.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Away! 'Tis the vulgar cant of common place vice.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You are yourſelf the victim of this depravity.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I feel I am. I find myſelf enſnared, unprotected, and in your power. But if you hope to bend me to diſhoneſt purpoſes, I ſmile at your impotence.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am no enemy, but a determined and active friend.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A friend!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I conjure you to conquer for a moment your ſuſpicions and fears. Grant me an attentive hearing.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Well, Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You are an injured orphan. The heireſs to great wealth, of which you have been wickedly deprived. I am bleſſed in being your deliverer. Pardon me for boaſting, but I glory that by my efforts the iniquity has been diſcovered.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: If that were true, what need was there for the compulſion you have practiſed?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How ſhall I anſwer? How expiate a fault that perhaps is unpardonable? Yet ſurely my crime itſelf will plead ſome abatement in my favour! 'Tis vain in me to falter—I love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Love!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Ay, to diſtraction!—Why do you regard me with that ſovereign diſdain? My life, faculties, and ſoul, ſhall exhauſt themſelves to yield you pleaſure. I petition for that which a weak or
preſumptuous man would claim as a due, but which I will hoard in my heart as the precious boon of the divinity whom I adore.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: The blandiſhment of words can neither diſguiſe nor palliate unworthy actions. Had your proceedings been open and direct, no taint of ſuſpicion would have glanced on the profeſſions you make, or the benefits which you ſay you have the power to confer, and I ſhould have felt a bitter pang in refuſal. But, were my affections free, nay, had they before been devotedly yours, the deceit you have employed, and the planned artifice of which I find you capable, would have placed an eternal barrier between us.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If you knew the firm purpoſe of my ſoul to make you happy— (Suſan watching)

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Pleading is vain.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Seizing her hand, but falling on his knee) I would fain prevail by ſoft and gentle means.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Do you threaten?

div.stage: (Suſan ſtill approaching, but with great trepidation)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: When you ſhall find how true how tender my heart can be, you will hereafter pardon the preſumption of this moment. (Riſing) Should I loſe it, you and happineſs were loſt for ever. (Claſping her.)

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Stand off!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: My fate— (Sees his ſiſter, and ſtamps.) How now!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Falling on her knees before him with her hands claſped) Harry!—Kill me—Put me out o' the world.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Violently) Get up.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I canno'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Leave the room.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I munno'. (Monroſe ſeizes her by the arm, and

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Hold, or turn upon me. (They collar each other.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Boy!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Forbear—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No ſuch boy, you find. I am not ſo eaſily to be ſhaken off. I am of the bull-dog breed. Damme I would muzzle any mad animal that ſhould attempt to toſs my ſweet Suſan. (Monroſe walks up the ſtage in violent perturbation.)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Aurelia, are you ſafe?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Perfectly. Thanks to my kind and faithful friend here. (To Suſan.)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: The chariot of Sir Guy is below: Do you, my brother, and Miſs Monroſe, return to my father's. Sir Guy is there. I muſt endeavour to bring this violent man.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay but will not that be dangerous?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Fear nothing. I am calm. I am prepared; and you know my principles. His preſence is abſolutely neceſſary.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Earneſtly) Surely, ſurely, you dunno' mean to harm brother Harry?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Harm him? No!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's a good mon's ſon, and I hope a'll be a good mon himſel'. I do hope and truſt a wull. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV. OLIVER following to the door, and MONROSE advancing lays hold of his arm.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A word with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Willingly. Your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You and I it ſeems are rivals. Time is precious, and I ſhall be brief. Yield your pretenſions to Aurelia.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: By what right, Sir, do you make this abrupt and peremptory demand?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By the right that every man has to guard his own happineſs.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: And that right juſtifies my refuſal.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Sir, I am an angry man; an injured man; a determined man. My ſoul is on the ſtretch: my ſpirits are flaming. Beware of me!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am aware of you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I have riſked my all. This is the criſis of my fate; and either comply, or one of us ſhall never depart alive.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Your threats are impotent.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then my deeds ſhall be deciſive. (Produces piſtols) Take this.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: For what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A gentleman need not aſk.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Jargon!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No delay! Aurelia is yours or mine.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Are you an aſſaſſin?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do aſſaſſins furniſh their enemy with weapons?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: If murder muſt be committed, the glory muſt be all your own: for never ſhall this arm be levelled at the life of man.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Damnation! Coward! Fire!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Fire you, madman!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Hell!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p:
Think you I am to be bullied into what you call courage? If you are ſo wound up to murder, begin! Here is your mark! Take your level! A ſhot through the heart, or a bullet through the
brain. Then vaunt of your dexterity; and again reiterate your epithet, gentleman.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Gnaſhing) To be thus baffled!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Abandon your purpoſe, or diſpatch: for not all the arguments of hell, nor all its fiends, ſhall drive me to ſhed the blood of human being.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To be thus tamed! Oh! Idiot! I the maſter of accident? Fool! Fool! I am the very ſlave of prejudice.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What! Is an antipathy to crime, prejudice?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Peremptorily) Leave me, Sir—to my own contempt. I am what I deſpiſe, a braggart.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Thank heaven! There are many braggarts in vice. You are a better man than you ſuppoſed. 'Tis no uncommon character. Remember then that Aurelia requires your aid.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Peace! I will be no man's automaton: will hear no pleadings. I am the lord of my own actions, and will be ſelf-moved.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You have a loftineſs of ſoul which I love: purſue its dictates.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (After a pauſe) It ſhall be ſo! Monroſe ſhall yet riſe on the necks of wretches that hope ere this to trample him in the duſt. Follow and behold! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V. The Houſe of SIR JOB.
div.stage: Enter SIR GUY and MR. TAUNTON.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, ſnail, how came Aurelia to be creeping acroſs fields with you at that time of night?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I—I—I don't know how it came.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why did you not fight, and defend her?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I fight, indeed! Talk of guns, but don't go near them.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
You ſay it was within a hundred yards of
a houſe. Why did not you bawl for help? Owls can hoot; and geeſe can cackle.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Really you croſs queſtion one like an Old Bailey barriſter!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And, really, you anſwer like an Old Bailey witneſs.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I only know that I took Aurelia out to walk; and that ſome ruffians ruſhed from behind a hedge, and carried her off.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It's a damned ſtrange ſtory; and a ſtrange affair too!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I hope you don't ſuſpect me, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why ſhould you ſuppoſe I ſuſpect you?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now, Sampſon, is there any news of them yet? Are they come back? Are they ſafe?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I hear nothing.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You ſeem to care nothing.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) I wiſh I had no cauſe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And pray how do you mean to provide for Oliver?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I? Which way muſt I provide?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) This fellow will tempt me to cut his throat.—Marry him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Why I have thought of that. A wife's fortune might do the buſineſs. But he—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Look at me—To a wife without a fortune.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Suſpecting) Hay? What?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How, Sir Guy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To the richeſt, pooreſt woman in England!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Who is that, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Aurelia Roland, Balaam.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Why, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (In the ſame tone) Sir Guy!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir Job! Sir Jack a lent! What the devil are you both petrified?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: How is ſhe rich?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: In beauty, in mind, in virtue.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh! Is that all?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: They can't pay for a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She is friendleſs, fatherleſs, portionleſs.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You have told one, two, three—hem!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who is her friend?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am. (Both alarmed)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who is her father?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Who is her banker?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You talk in the clouds. You are not her father.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Who made you a judge? What do you know about fathers? He is a father that has a father's affection, and will perform a father's duties.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but—Will you, Sir Guy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Yes I will, Sir Gooſe!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide to Mr. Taunton) What ſhall we do? We ſhall be blown.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) I told you what would come of it. Feaſt with fools, and fare as they do.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I don't know. (Knocking heard, Sir Guy croſſes to the door)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is ſhe! Here ſhe comes!

div.head: SCENE VII. Enter AURELIA, SUSAN, and JONAS.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Guy!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear girl, here you are once more ſafe and free.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Taking Suſan's hand) Yes, and here is her deliverer.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, indeed!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, this dear, courageous, affectionate girl is the ſaviour of us all. While my heart beats, ſhe ſhall have a warm place in it.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: She will have a warm place in other people's hearts as well as yours.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh ho!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But are you ſure though, are you deadly ſure that nobody will bring brother Harry to ſhame?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Moſt certain. (Aſide) And yet I wiſh Oliver and he were returned.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: It is time, I ſee, for me to be moving.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, curlew, do you forebode a ſtorm?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I can't tell. High winds ruin a fair harveſt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Stay where you are, I tell you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I can't ſtay, and I won't ſtay.

div.head: SCENE VIII. Enter OLIVER and MONROSE.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yet ſtay you muſt, Sir. Your preſence is neceſſary in court. Here am I a bold faced knave that appear without a ſummons, and call on you as one of my accuſers. Sir Job ſhall be another.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aſide) I wiſh I was any where but in this houſe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "'Tis no uncommon caſe for the leaſt criminal to be condemned by his accomplices."

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aſide to Monroſe) Are you mad? Why did you come here?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
(Aloud) Why not come here, Sir? I aſk not you to bluſh for any crime of mine. Which of you ſober ſeniors will ſit as my judge? (Turning to Sir Guy) Your pardon, Sir, my words do not
glance at you. Be my actions what they will, I can diſtinguiſh, ay, and can reverence virtue.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Go on: No apologies, I am no better than I ſhould be.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well then, here I ſtand, and put myſelf upon my country. "What is my crime? A ſovereign contempt for the ſelfiſhneſs to which genius and virtue are the daily ſacrifice; and, ſince honeſty could procure me neither favor nor fortune, a reſolution to be no longer its dupe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Syſtematic vice of all others is the moſt dangerous."

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fellows like me, thrown on the pavement, and wanting the varniſh of gold and hypocriſy, give us but a bad name, and any idiot can trace halters in every feature. But turn here! Behold theſe grey beards! How ſmooth is all without! How ſanctified is all within! How ſedate is every hair and wrinkle! Have ſires like theſe their ſecret ſins? Can they plunder the orphan, perſecute the innocent, and diſturb the aſhes of the dead until they riſe and cry for vengeance?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: "Have patience.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Proceed then! Arraign me at your bar, claſs me with villains, load me with opprobrium and puniſhment; then contraſt my actions, my character, my crimes, with theſe honeſt, theſe magiſterial men; and, having ſo done, raiſe the whip, ſtrike, and applaud the wiſdom of your laws, and the juſtice of your deciſions.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is this reality?"

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did I ſeek ſupport in villany by example, think you I ſhould want precedents? (Taking Sir Job and Mr. Taunton each by the hand) Stand forth, reverend iniquity! Here are we three!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is moſt ſtrange! (Knocking hard at the ſtreet door) What more?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this, Mr. Taunton? Here is the parlour full of Bow-ſtreet runners, keeping your attorney in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (In great terror) Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: It's all over. (Sir Job and Mr. Taunton are endeavouring to retire)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you muſt not flinch. Stand to it, and if you have nerves ſtring them! Behold this lady. (Pointing to Aurelia) Look at the lovely daughter of your generous mutual and confiding friend! Dying, he bequeathed the expiring mother and the helpleſs infant, not to your humanity but your juſtice. Where is the wealth he depoſited in truſt? Full fifty thouſand pounds, with the accumulating ſtock of twenty years! Anſwer! Has it been huſbanded well? Produce the ſtatement.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Good heavens!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Left to that charity which ever finds ſome gentle breaſt to hide in, here ſhe ſtands, if hearts you had, with wrong enough to wring thoſe hearts in pangs unutterable.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Are theſe things poſſible?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: My witneſſes are ready. Let him that dare deny the charge.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Taunton! Have you no anſwer? (Short pauſe.)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nor you, Sir Job? (He turns away.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My blood runs cold! This man my brother?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Their ſilence is their aſſent.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: The Lady ſhall have her due. The tree of knavery bears bitter fruit. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Brother is a brave mon! I knew a wur! I knew a had it about him!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am choaked! I could not ſay a word to the fellow.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) Well, Sir, will you follow your leader's example?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay, ay; I have followed it a little too often!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What, aſhamed of knavery at theſe years!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I ſhall never ſhew my face in the City.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "Ha, ha, ha! The City? Why, man, you and I are petty knaves! Conſole yourſelf: crimes of a much deeper dye no longer are a nine days wonder. Some friendly ſcandal, with `Bleſs me, who would have thought it!' and a little groſs abuſe, which you'll not hear, is the utmoſt penalty. Meanwhile bows, ſalutations, and grinning courteſy will be current as ever. 'Tis only the needy villain that is ſhunned."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Heigho! It is bad I find to do wrong: but it is worſe to be found out. [Exit.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Your reproof is ſevere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why, ay. I am ſtill a diſciple of the world and its maxims; I can perſecute vice in others and practiſe it myſelf like any potent Don in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, Sir, that a fellow of your ſoul ſhould claſs himſelf with knaves.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nothing is ſtrange. Man is all a contradiction. I thought myſelf an adept, I find myſelf a tyro. He that would ſucceed in knavery, muſt be wholly knave. I have compunctions and ſympathies which a man muſt either ſhake off or go hide in honeſt obſcurity.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: "Are talents and genius, then, no recommendation?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Talents and genius are the admiration of a day: ſo is a calf with two heads, or any other monſter."

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (With affectionate timidity) Brother Harry—Wull thee forgi' me?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Forgive thee, girl! My ſoul adores thy kind and honeſt nature.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (In tears) I love thee, Harry! I love thee!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Catching her feelings) And damme but ſo do I!—I love you all.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, how bleſſed is this moment! How grateful to my heart is the little power which wealth can give! (To Suſan) My everlaſting friend. (To Monroſe and Sir Guy) And you my ſaviour, you my protector.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Not a word for me?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Will not a look ſuffice?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (With dejection) You are a happy man, Sir.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: (To Monroſe) You have proved the dignity of your mind. You have gained friends that will never forſake you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (To Aurelia) The Goodneſs bleſs you! I ſaid from the firſt I loved you dearly.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I find I am quite left out among you! (To Suſan) Surely you don't forget your promiſe?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What wur that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Imitating Suſan) "I ſhall love you to the lateſt breath I draw."

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Abaſhed) No, no, I hanno' forgotten.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why then, my Lady—You know what▪

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, but, my dear Jonas—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, her Ladyſhip will freely conſent, and will be happy to dance a reel at your wedding.—Well, I have hitherto lived, and fear I ſhall die wondering at the enormous vices, and the ſplendid virtues, which mingle and form the hiſtory of that motley creature man.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And what is it that will correct his errors? It is the virtue that has been exerciſed to day. It is purity of intention in ſome, benevolence of heart in others, and that kind, forgiving, and indulgent ſpirit, which ought to inhabit every human boſom. [Exeunt Onmes.
